reviewText: Even after several years, this game still looks and plays well.  A shame they never got to release all of the armies, but it's still fun to go in and enjoy a game with friends.  Last Stand was a suprise hit that is remarkably entertaining for something so simple in its setup.  All in all, this game is definately worth your time and money.  Now integrated with Steamworks, there is renewed hope that Sega may bring the series back with more titles - fingers crossed !

reviewText:
As a developer, what would you do when your game is loved by a dedicated fanbase, but mired in dislike for it's stifling DRM? You make a stand alone expansion that is six times the original game and streamline it for an excellent online experience. Good guy Relic.

Real Time Tactical Roleplaying Game. That is how I would describe Dawn of War Retribution. It is focussed on character building, and using special abilities to clear obstacles and objectives. Clearning these obstacles rewards you with gear and other sweet loot to use and to adapt to circumstances. However, unlike the original Dawn of War 2, this one does it with more than just the Space Marines. This time round the campaign is open to the zealous Space Marines, the dogmatic Imperial Guard,  the enigmatic Eldar, the barbaric Orks, the horrific Tyrranids and the eldritch Chaos Marines. Each faction proceeds through the same story and events, but does so for a different purpose. The Space Marines need to clear their name, as their chapter master allegedly has fallen to Chaos, while the Eldar pursue the same cause to prevent their planets from being destroyed by the Inquisition. The Orks just want to fight and the Tyrranids hunger. The voice acting in the game is top notch and delivers the ruminations of each character with gusto and panachel; Slightly over the top, yet in tune with the material. The overal experience is entertaining and diverse, allowing for many hours of gameplay on your own, or with a friend.

The game also features and extensive multiplayer component to go head to head. It plays like your ordinary RTS, but allows for so much customisation in regards to outfits and paintjobs. You might be forgiven for thinking that Valve made this game. The overal experience is a fast paced stratagem, with more focus on skirmishes between parties than massive clashes between armies.

The last mode, and perhaps the most entertaining is Last Stand. In this mode, you and two others try to fend off twenty waves of enemy hordes with customised hero units. The mode is amazing for its many options and rewarding gameplay. No matter how far you come, the game will always reward you with points or items for your effort. Get a friend to two and tackle this beast. You will be entertained.

I could go on to muse this game for another while, but if you're not really into the compact rts style, or Warhammer for that matter, then this game might not be your cup of tea. It can also get a bit boring after five campaigns. Especially the more human oriented races do feel a bit stale after a while.

What? Of course not! Humans? Stale? Art thou mad? Humanity shall prevail. The Emperor wills it. The day that Chaos rules the minds of men shall never come. Stand fast fellow warrior and join us in the eternal battle against the foul beings that the vile warp hath unleashed. Forget you money; human lives are the Emperor's currency. So spend it well, and pay your debt to his Greatness!

reviewText:
the singleplayer campaign isnt too good but its also not very bad. repetitive levels though and a rather weak and short told story. still i had fun to hunt the achievements there and to play it with friends in coop-mode. bit annoying bugs there were, even before the migration from winlive to steam when achievements wont unlock, i had to play some races multiple times to trigger them.
the multiplayer is really great though. its just a good concept to ignore base building (which is boring in my opinion) and focus on the micro management of your army fighting for points. i like the great variety of units and abilities which allow different playstyles and lots of strategies. the biggest issue is and was the small player count in the multiplayer mode, still you find and found enough to pretty much always get some games going.
the greatest mode for me is the last stand mode, i dropped hundreds, if not thousands, hours into leveling my heroes and playing for score or just for fun or to help others. it never gets old and you can always jump back in after some time. you will always find players there immediately.
really poor is the support from relic though. the game still has quite a few bugs, especially after the migration from winlive, where the game started, to steam. this update really put a lot of new bugs in the game and took some good functions away and more or less was left in this state.
there is also a so called elite mod, which truely most veteran multiplayer gamer play today. its different balanced and features some more units and even a new faction. personally i dont like the balance there and prefer the balance in the original game. it ever and ever gets modified which maybe has a charme in its own, so you can adjust yourself ever again.
after all superb game. im hoping on dow 3. but i dont have great confidence in relic when i see all the balance mess they made in coh2 (which is now after quite some years, at least at the point im writing this, in a decent state, but the way it took...)

reviewText:
When I was 10, I asked my dad for a bb gun, I'm fairly certain he said no at that very moment, but being 10 I didn't hear him, and went around putting fliers from toys r' us in all of his stuff ala Christmas story with bbguns circled,
well come christmas I did not recieve a bbgun.
I got Warhammer Fantasy Battle.
I looked at my dad, and he just laughed, and told me something like go play
I did.
I don't think to this day he realizes what he gave me.
For inside was the warhammer rule book, and this contained not only the rules of playing the first versions of warhammer tabletop, but also the stories and art of warhammer.
I was instantly enthralled, blood, violence, betrayal, sacrifice, crazy insane heroes, epic battles
skip ahead to my discovery of 40k and the fleshing out of the warhammer universe and story led me to consume the books, and art of the universe, my world has never been the same, I gave up Christianity because Jesus couldn't hold his own against Khorne, I mean really, Peace be with you? Lame.
now I'll actually get to  DOW2:Retribution,
Take the massive epic scale of warhammer, condense it down, down to small unit tactics, and you get  to the very heart of Warhammer, the tales of Individual squads and heroes taking part in the struggle of the  Eternal Galactic War,
Every race is  balanced to a T, what at first appears to be a very limited set of units, and heroes, actually becomes an incredible and fluid tactics game, the ebb and flow of battle, the constant tug of war, ambushes, assaults, defenses,  last stands,  the epic clashes of heroes, and dread warmachines,
This is hands down, the best multiplayer Warhammer Game, it captures a very beautiful piece of this amazing universe and brought it to new life for me.
Blood for the blood god, and skulls for the skull throne!

reviewText:
Gameplay wise, it has deviated a bit from the traditional Dawn Of War 2 campaigns in favour of a more Dawn Of War - Dark Crusade like meta campaign. You can now choose between Space Marines, Eldar, Orks, Chaos and the Imperial Guard. The campaigns are the same for everyone, however each race has their own agenda. But the goal of every race is to eliminate Azariah Kyras. That means even though the campaign feels redundant, it is refreshing to be able to change tactics and play the campaign as other races.

Retribution also brings some diversity to the campaigns, such that unlike the previous Dawn Of War 2 installments, you can now further diversify your forces by replacing your regular deployable hero units with other honor guard units, depending upon your play style or according to what sort of opposition you expect to face in the campaign. You can also now field a larger number of squads by capturing Relay Beacons (or equivalent for races other than the Space Marines) and call in additional squads or vehicles subject to the amount of Requisition you have captured during your battle. This makes your campaign similar to a skirmish game albeit with campaign like objectives.

You can also gain traits for your hero units faster since you get a guaranteed trait every time you level up, unlike previous Dawn Of War 2 installments, where you have to level up 2-3 times before you get a trait.

Though I feel its somewhat inferior to DOW2 and Chaos Rising story-wise, it is nonetheless interesting to see how the story ends for the Blood Ravens in the Space Marine campaign (which I believe is canon for this series).

reviewText:
INTRODUCTION:
Dawn of War II: Retribution is the third and final expansion to the Dawn of War II titles. (Also see my Reviews for Dawn of War II and Dawn of War II: Chaos Rising).

The story takes place after the events of Chaos Rising where Gabriel Angelos and his followers were labeled as renegades by their own Chapter Master Azariah Kyras. With the Tyranid invasions, Ork assaults, Chaos Incursions and Eldar Raids, the Imperium has had enough and has now sent the Inquisition to wipe Sub-sector Aurelia from the Galaxy. The player assumes the role of Captain Apollo Diomedes of the Blood Ravens Honor Guard in his quest to uncover the truth about his Brothers and the Chapter Master he serves.

PROS:
+ More Factions in the Singleplayer Campaign: -  It is refreshing to see that Relic decided to bring back their old formula where other factions are now playable. This includes, Orks, Eldar, Chaos, Imperial Guard and Tyranids. No Tau though.

+ Active Multiplayer Scene: - I normally don't care about Multiplayer in games but I found it very impressive that there still exists a very active online multiplayer community. Last Stand is always fun to play.

+ Imperial Guard: - This faction is the latest addition to the multiplayer / skirmish mode and is very fun to play. Well balanced in my opinion and has added new and interesting characters with likable personalities like Sergeant Merrick.

+ Hero Replacement: - You can now field special Honor Guard units rather than the Hero units you are given. Example: Leave Scout Sergeant Cyrus and deploy a Terminator Honor Guard Squad instead.

CONS:
- Dumbed Down Action RPG Element: - What made the Dawn of War II Campaign unique was its RPG elements. It was seriously disappointing to see it virtually stripped to its bare minimum with only 10 levels as the cap and severely limited wargear selections.

- Poor pathfinding: - Some of the larger vehicles will literally block your army from passing through and will do some really strange movements when it tries to make room for them to pass through. This will result in a very disorganized troop movement specially in some of the smaller maps, or maps with very narrow bottlenecks.

- Short Campaigns: - As a whole, the entire campaign is long if you play through all the factions, but individually, they are shorter than the previous titles with some very weak or hastily put together plot.

- Some unresolved bugs: - At the time of this review the game should be 3 years old but still I encounter bugged missions or bugged units and sometimes out right crashes. Not game breaking but this should have been fixed a long time ago.

CONCLUSION:
GOOD EXPANSION BUT I WOULD RECOMMEND PLAYING THROUGH THE ORIGINAL GAME AND CHAOS RISING FIRST. Retribution adds new factions and units to the game both in Single and Multiplayer, it gives back life to the series with a lot of interesting new characters and story. It does suffer from a rather weak campaign when compared to the original, but makes up for it in a fun multiplayer experience.

New players might enjoy this more for the multiplayer / skirmish rather than the story so I recommend new players to try the original Dawn of War II and Chaos Rising first or even the first Dawn of War game if they want to be invested in the Story.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

reviewText:
This game is everything you could want from a Warhammer 40k RTS. It functions just like company of heroes, probably because theyre both made by relic

Overall this is a wonderfull game to get if you like warhammer 40k. Theirs 6 factions to play as, each with its own unique machanics and play style, The Space Marines, The Imperial Guard, The Eldar, The Tyranids, Chaos, and my personal Favorite, The Orks

each faction has 3 different commanders you can deploy and the game is very well balanced, the sories are decent, and fun, but sometimes lacking depth

Multiplayer is the key feature of this game, as it is the most fun you'll have. Stand against an ork waaaahg, or a tyranid invasion, or fight against the ruinous powers as the guard or the angels of death. The games are just long enough, and the learning curve isnt too severe if you know how to play an RTS

The Elite mod for this game has kept the community alive, as it rebalences the game, adds new units and another faction (The Grey Knights) and is updated frequently. The community for it holds monthly tournaments, has a number of game casters, and is overall a great community

Pros
+ 6 differnt factions that are very distinct from one another in how they play
+ Lots of maps and worlds to choose from
+ Graphics are pretty good
+ Lots of different units for every army, as well as commanders
+ good resource managment
+ Multiplayer is amazing
+ campaigns are pretty fun
+ Elite mod has completely taken over as the official support and keeps the game alive
+ AI is decently challanging
+ Lots of solid DLC that isnt stupidly expensive and can easily be forgone if you dont want them

Cons
- Only 2 multiplayer modes
- Only can have 2 teams in multiplayer, so no massive 6 army free for alls, which was a wasted oportunity in my opinion
- No more official support as THQ doesnt exist anymore
- Controls are a bit wonky
- Unit pathing can be weird at times

On the whole, this game is well worth the mere $30 it asks for, and theirs plenty of DLC for it that is great, such as more wargear for you campaign commanders, more skins for multiplayer armies, and additional gear for the last stand

i give this game 10/10 Ork stormboyz rocketing into the imperial guard lines. Get the game, you wont regret it

reviewText:
Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II: Retribution is an excellent RTS-style game where base-building itself is dropped, in favor of more strategic combat involvement. While this may seem initially like a dumbing-down from DoWI, the playstyle it encourages is more fast-paced, usually more aggressive, and leads itself to large armies splitting off across the map. This has ended up being a very fun way to play an RTS.

The campaign has benefited from this style in that in place of a Commander unit, you can have up to four Heroes that are powerful (typically single-person) units with Wargear upgrades and stat boosts while in a mission. These heroes can be substitued for an Honor Guard unit, which is a stronger version of a standard army unit. While building an army is fun, I also had a blast clearing the missions with only my Heroes and their witty banter.

Multiplayer has become faster, which is usually a plus, as it allows us to play more games, or to boot up a match when normally we couldn't. I enjoy that gameplay feels more aggressive, with players capturing Requisition Points and Power Nodes in order to increase the speed that accumulate resources to purchase army units, and with holding the Victory Points, in which you must hold more than your opponent for a period of time in order to win. This leads to a very active playstyle, where you're balancing defensive capabilities with offensive, and mobility with firepower. Nearly every unit has potential upgrades, either as stat increases or new weapons, allowing them to be good against, and bad against, different types of enemies. Something as small as purchasing a few Flamers will make your unit that much stronger with melee engages, and constantly staying one step ahead of your enemy in upgrades, or creating units to counter their build, will often be the deciding factor of whether you fall from grace, or rise in glory as a successful tactician. The Hero system also carries into Multiplayer, as you select from one of six races, then one of three Hero units per race. These Heroes have different skills and Racial Abilities, and encourage different playstyles. Similar to the Campaign, these Hero units can purchase Wargear ingame once they have met the requirements (per game, no carrying over), to grant higher stats and capabilities against different enemies.

The Last Stand, also sold as an individual DLC package, is a great mode where three players try to survive, and conquer, 20 waves of enemies. Each player selects a Hero and their Wargear before entering queue, with seven different Heroes, and a LOT of Wargear options. Mirrors are possible, but do not generally affect gameplay, and will likely have different builds. Wargear is obtained through leveling up, where you gain experience points at the end of the game, or through special, sometimes difficult, achievements. Most Heroes have two achievement Wargear unlocks. The Last Stand is incredibly brutal, very unforgiving, and you may never beat it. Players have the ability to revive fallen teammates, though this immobilizes the reviver, and reduces their firepower greatly, easily causing their death as well. Also on the map are two Point Multiplying Nodes, similar in appearance to Power Nodes, that add a x3 multiplier to your team's score each. Certain types of enemies will try to capture these points for themselves. Each Hero is vastly different, and every team composition is as well, leading to immense replayability, especially if you haven't beaten either of the two maps yet... (It's always that blasted Wave 20! ;-;)

Lore-wise this game is both engaging and genuinely gets the grimdark feel of the WH40k universe. As the story progressed, through the earlier two campaigns (DoWII and DoWII:Chaos Rising) and this one, I felt the tragedies come one after the other, and each victory feeling less and less impactful until you get that one killing blow that just brings everything you've done all together, and you can feel the weight just disappear off of your chest, and you sit back in the chair and let out this sigh of relief... until you are informed of another emergency happening almost immediately. It kept me on the edge of my seat with its grimdarkness, its surprisingly fitting comedy (especially playing as those 'ard Ork boyz), and my genuine interest in how it was going to play out. While a lot of people feel that the campaign is short, and it kinda is, it certainly isn't lacking in content or gameplay, and it was very fun.

Pros        Cons                Engaging campaign, interesting and fitting characters, fun take on an RTS.        Short campaign that may be a little lackluster if you haven't played the other campaigns in earlier games.                Fun multiplayer design that encourages constant action.        May take a while to get into the mode as there is a lot to learn, and a lot to manage.                The Last Stand is a great mode with high replayability and a fun premise.        May be repetetive, harder for lower-levels which may discourage Hero diversity, and one Hero is locked behind paid DLC.
TL;DR: 9/10 A very fun game that successfully captured the essence of the WH40k universe, and gave me three fun modes to play. There is a modding community as well, keeping it alive, and encouraging its growth. I highly recommend it to any WH40k or RTS fan.

reviewText: In the mold of the Dark Crusade expansion for the original Dawn of War, Retribution allows you to play a campaign for each available faction. Unfortunately, the Risk-style campaign map present in Dark Crusade does not exist in Retribution. Instead, each faction plays an almost identical campaign on a set path, with the only major differences being the characters you use and what your characters say. While it's fun to play the new heroes from each faction, the campaign rapidly becomes repetitive. I played through the space marine and ork campaigns and had fun, but I couldn't bring myself to finish yet another campaign with a virtually identical story and identical missions.\n\nNot recommended.

reviewText:
Almost 5 years old and still going strong, Dawn of War II Retribution is a pretty fun game that'll keep you coming back for more with its addictive gameplay and strategic battle scenarios. It's not entirely perfect, but it can be a very enjoyable game for both old and new fans of the Warhammer 40K series.

The Pros Awesome intro
Six playable races (Space marines, Chaos, Imperial Guard, Eldar, Orks, and Tyranids)
The Last Stand is the most addicting. Eight heroes(two of whtich are DLC) to choose from, 20 waves of enemies to fight off, and each of the two maps has special gimmicks to make the experience different.
Can create custom color schemes for each race to use in Multiplayer and Last Stand
Pretty cheap when it goes on sale
Mods make it fun for those who play the Multiplayer mode by adding new units and increased pop cap (+300!)
Final boss is fun to fight
Lots of potential for a Dawn of War III
You cam wage a massive WAAAGH!
TYRANIDS!!!!

The Cons  Campaign is repetative. Each race goes through the exact same missions with different dialogue, different commanders, different units, and different prologue and epilogue cutscenes.
Some glitches have yet to be patched. Don't worry, there isn't that many
Multiplayer is not as newb friendly as Last Stand. If you haven't played the first four Dawn of War games, stay away from it
Tau Efficiency achievement
100 unit pop cap in Multiplayer makes it hard to get a good assault.
Dark Eldar Archon and Sisters of Battle Canoness are not DLC heroes for Last Stand  :'(  Some DLC isnt worth it even when on sale, specifically the ones for Multiplayer that offer special color schemes that dont appear in Last Stand
Space Marine and Imperial Guard campaign DLC is $2 whilst all other campaign DLC is $1
Space Marine ending is only canonical ending
No third map for Last Stand
While it does have it's fair share of ups and downs, you can always be sure it will keep you coming back for more

9.5/11 Here's to hoping they got something big planned for this game's 5th anniversary! -chugs fungus beer- WAAAAAAAAHG!!!!!!
voteText: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The last installment of Dawn of War II. Finally you can play as any race in the single player campaign. There is no carryover component from the previous games, and the game itself is standalone. The abilities and wargear are fairly fun to customize, and the game is not hard even on the highest setting. A second map was added to the multiplare arcade mode, which was harder waves than the first. There is a purchaseable arcade-mode DLC that adds a Tau crisis/broadside unit as a playable hero, which is very interesting.

I guess overall this has to be my favourite series of all time, although I don't play this game at all anymore. Across the three games in this series I have logged almost 1000 hours of play, most of which was single player.

Maybe it's a bad idea to review all three games under one title, but they are best viewed as parts of a whole. The vanilla game was really challenging when played on Primarch; there was an intricate re-deployment system that encouraged you to play every mission to the best of your ability, as well as a ton of wargear that wasn't guarenteed to drop at fixed points. Chaos rising was my favourite, offering maximal flexibility in squadmates, gear, playstyle and choices. Once the Chaos Rising patch is applied to the vanilla game, playing the vanilla part on hardest becomes really hard. The Corruption system in Chaos rising was great, decently complex, and have a bearing on the ending. Retribution was the easiest game out of the three, but you can play as any race you want and the ending is open-ended. Once again, Retribution does not require the first two games to play, and it has no carryover mechanic, although the storyline is officially continuous. If you don't like to play as space marines but like the single player aspect, just play Retribution.

reviewText: A wonderful take on RTS. reviewText:
After 20 minuites of waiting you will find a 3v3 game with the people on your team unable to speak english. one of them will have left his mic next to a swarm of angry bees the other will swear at you in a language you cant understand.

Then the match starts.

Three seconds later you realise the other team is a clan that all play as the same race and abuses the ♥♥♥♥ out of whatever exploit relic has failed to patch this week.

You abandon all hope of victory.

During the opening 30 seconds of the match the frame rate falls into single figures as the ping of one guy on the other team skyrockets.

Somebody from your side is kicked from the match, It wasnt the guy with the broken mic.

Finally after half an hour of grinding away the other team rolls out a super weapon that your army has no counter too. You watch as it slowly swaggers towards your base and teabags all your units to death.

You will call a vote to concede the match, your team mate will refuse before ragequiting, leaving you unable to end the match with any honour still intact.

I love this game.

reviewText:
DOW2: Retribution is a disappointing step back from the previous Dawn of War 1 and even the base Dawn of War 2. The campaign of Retribution is a set of cloned missions identical for each race; unit customization and commander/specialty unit progression is too simple and lumpy compared to DoW2 vanilla. This cloned campaign does not even have the charm of the set of same missions from DoW1: Dark Crusade or DoW1: Soulstorm, because there is no aspect of base-building or sufficiently different strategic playstyles. While the overall storyline is not bad, the cloned nature of the campaign makes it utterly predictable after the first time you've played it, and the only virtue to playing through it again is to earn more achievements or to cheer on your second-favorite race.
Gameplay in DoW2: Retribution is average; most units either suffer from a rock-paper-scissors balance mechanism, or are powerfully broken. Early game for a lot of races is slow and frustrating, as you must focus more on obtaining and securing resources than getting stuck in with your archnemesis. Whoever controls the power nodes wins. Between the focus on resource-gathering and the small size of the armies, this game could be reskinned to any other given RTS and you'd never know the difference; there is very little that sets this game apart as distinctly Warhammer 40K.

Overall I can't give this game more than a 6/10. Relic and Games Workshop have quite a bit to make up for if they go through with DoW3.

reviewText:
DAWN OF WAR II RETRIBUTIONDawn of War II Retribution is the second expansion and third edition of the Relic Entertainment RTS Dawn of War II (2009), following its predecessor Chaos Rising (2010). It takes the setting of the 41st millenium and lets the player experience it from a tactical combat perspective, controlling resources to build a better, more refined army than your opponent in order to claim victory.

The game consists of three main elements as well as side features. These are as follows:

MULTIPLAYERThe meat of the game for most players is the dynamic multiplayer which allows for intense tactical combat in 1v1 to 3v3, free for all and team free for all. The mainstay is the victory point control mode, a system whereby the winner is the first to drain their opponent out of victory points, whereas annihilation mode, where victory is the destruction of the enemy base, is slightly simpler. The multiplayer has many strenghts that have seen it through a prosperous lifespan:

- Very in-depth tactical combat
- Asymmetrical faction balance
- Dynamic map design
- Well balanced commander mechanics
- Unique flow and pacing
- Tactical combat that does not require lots of APM but perfect execution and follow-up

However it harbours some flaws:

- The unmodded game has certain poor balance choices
- The ranked multiplayer is mostly dead due to stagnation and broken leaderboards
- A few maps are almost unplayable in their lack of quality
- The game has not received a balance patch since late 2011
- The multiplayer is incredibly challenging and thus very hard to get into

The game itself is very different to the one it followed up, Dawn of War, and this has turned many old DoW I players off it. I believe however the change is a necessary improvement to keep the franchise fresh, having been adapted from the Company of Heroes formula that proved to make a well established, well regarded RTS set in World War II.

It is well known that the game has mroe depth with mod, so you shoudl look at these in particular:
- Elite Balance Mod: http://www.dawnofwar.info
- Codex Edition Mod: https://steamcommunity.com/groups/DoW2-CE

CAMPAIGNAlthough perhaps not as well designed as the vanilla game's campaignh, it allows for playthroughs with all factions and thus has replayability. Take the squad based combat to explore the story further in somethign that is worth looking at to grasp some mechanics.

THE LAST STANDSimilar to a MOBA, this PvE aspect takes individual heroes in an arena and pits them against waves of enemy hordes. Especially fun with friends when you can combo each hero's abilities and work together, however sadly it only contains two different maps, though both play out differently.

FEATURESArmy Painter: Allows you to customise your warriors before going into battle to choose pre-loaded schemes or make your own, including allowing players upload their own custom badges.

Game History: Tracks all multiplayer stats so you can see just who and what you are losing to.

World Builder: A piece of software I have found myself in for many an hour which gives you all the tools the developers had when making maps, incredibly enthralling and I recommend Duncan's guide for working out how to use it: http://www.dowreplays.net/DOW-II-Map-Making-Guide.pdf

CONCLUSIONIt is an intensely tactical and strategic game with large depth and scope better with mods, but suffers from a thinning community and lack of developer support.

If you like a challenge and an experience with something that is so unique, this is definitely worth ti if you can get in with the community.

reviewText:
Building further upon the game's core concepts and ideas from Chaos Rising, this installment adds army building to the mix. The focus becomes less on your heroes and squads, and more on the overall plot, and its race/faction flavor.
More linear than DoWII but still quite a bit of fun. Heroes gain more traits but the game becomes exceptionally stingy on wargear for them.
Mission rewards offer you either 1 piece of wargear(in addition to the handful of items you find on a map) or unlocks/upgrades for your army units. Still not as good as Soulstorm or Dark Crusade but again a worthy title.
Definitely worth it on sale, and I'll have to rate this one at 4 outta 5. I guess I really missed the base building aspects as I was looking forward to an RTS, which this still doesn't quite feel like. Retribution does, however, have a much higher replayability than Chaos Rising or core DoWII

reviewText:
If there's anything I love about this game, is that it stays true to most of the parts of the original Dawn of War games, the only differences are, which, I honestly see as improvements, for the most part:

Removal of Morale system but addition of the Suppression system, this allowed you to slow incoming enemies and not only that, but have them under the manner of decreased accuracy.
Knockback still exists
Sadly, kill sync animations aren't as common as they once were, but this also is a bit of an enhancement, as killsyncs can happen too almost too frequently in the original Dawn of War, where you can still attack the enemy doing it and, as a result, you can waste abilities when they're simply immune to the damage.
Low and High cover still exists, thankfully, but bombed areas now serve as light cover, and even end up changing the floor texture of the map.
While not all of the units from the first set of games exist, a large majority of them are still around, and even then, they're replaced with similar functioning units (Possessed Chaos Marines to Bloodletters, Kasrkins to Stormtroopers, Flash Gitz to Kommandos, etc.)
Most infantry are less versatile, but as a result, have a bit more benefits. Soldiers can't be upgraded with every single thing.
There is no more armory/blacksmith upgrades. Upgrades are done specifically for squads. Level up system also serves as a bit of a HP and Energy upgrade, too.
Speaking of Energy, Energy system prevents massive spellspam then retreat.
Voice Acting is wonderfully done, where some lines in Dawn of War I wasn't that well done, along with a bit of humor from characters' voice lines.
Shiny paint for the armies now exists.

The only bad improvements I've seen is;
Vehicles easily overpower most sorts of infantry, even if they do have anti-vehicle specialties. Vehicles are easily the meta unlike in Dawn of War II, where you use both vehicles and soldiers to their best course of action.
Population stays locked at 100, whereas the cap in Dawn of War is increased by base levels or sometimes, other means (such as building another certain building, for IG, building an Infantry Command post raises Infantry cap). This annoyed me, as I couldn't spread my group all over the map, and it made some battles very little instead of one huge battle.
There is no longer base building, which removes the feel of having your own base to use as well as making things less 'homey'
No more Listening Posts, this especially frustrated me.
Retreat functions can be especially annoying, where even if ranged hits do land a shot, they do very minor damage, where melee does significantly larger damage (Vehicles at least can't retreat, however)
Vehicle vs. Hero, guess who wins?

Overall, however, this is still a very fun game, and I recommend trying it for it's humorous colors, well done voice acting, gameplay that still stays a bit true to the roots of the system.

P.S. SEGA, please make Dawn of War III or more expansions that would include some more races, such as the Dark Eldar, and the Tau.

reviewText:
One of my favourite RTS games.
The campaign consists of a somewhat linear series of missions where you receive rewards in form of items and upgrades for your heroes and units.
There are 6 different races (Space Marine, Imperial Guards, Tyranid, Chaos Marine, Ork and Eldar) which consists of four (4) heroes and several units.
When playing the campaign you primarily use your heroes but you can create units and switch your heroes to an Honor Guard (A free and stronger version of regular units).

In Multiplayer you can play from 1v1 to 4v4 and Free For All. There's ranked play and Custom Games. I mostly play the Campaign and The Last Stand but this is somewhat entertaining.

There's also a game-mode called The Last Stand in which you choose a hero, equip him/her with Wargear and then fight against up to 20 waves of enemies. There are 2 maps which varies in difficulty.

The game got good graphics and the gameplay is great but it's somewhat lacking in base building due to the fact that you only got your main building and the extra buildings you got available includes Turrets and sometime bunkers.
It's not fully optimized but it runs close to perfect for me, my Graphic cards gets a bit warm in the menu which is weird but other than that it works good.

I highly recommend it to players who enjoyed the earlier Dawn of War 2 games but for those who liked Dawn of War 1, don't expect the same building management.

I still hope that Dawn of War 3 is being developed but the future looks dark.

reviewText:
6/10 A very interesting, combat based RTS game with a pretty straightforward campaign. While up front this game seems like a well built game, it has some wierd balancing issues. Due to this, the selection for armies is pretty narrowed-down.

The first example shows itself in the 'army painter', a utility for players to further customize their forces. It seems unassuming at first, but upon closer inspection, the issues begin to show themselves. When selecting colors, there are a few colors that end up giving boons in gameplay. To summarize, the only colors that make tactical sense is red, because it is more or less direct upgrade from all the other colors.

Moving on to the army selection. This is where the balancing issues really start intervening with gameplay. The game includes many of the signature armies from Games-Workshop's tabletop game, most notably the Imperial Guard. Normally, each army has their own polarizations, such as one may be better at meelee combat, or one may be better at shooting. The problem here is, one of the armies, the Imperial Guard, is not polarized at all, and excells in all areas. This makes it the only real choice for players if they want to have a good experience. Some players actually try to cheat at the game in order to make armies like the Space Marines (the absolute worst faction) viable.

Dealing with both of these issues, I found myself very limited in my choices when actually playing. The only combo I ended up using were red Imperial Guardsmen (Guardsmen are the all around best unit in the Imperial Guard). Buy at your discretion.

reviewText:
LIES... lies. This is not the dawn of war but the beginning of the apocalypse. Do not trust the words of a serpent, unless you wish to be betrayed. I say this from experience...

I believed him whole heartedly, hehe, it is only fitting he took a part of my heart with him, when he left me here to die. If only I had seen him for who he was. How could I have been so blind?

What use is there for 20/20 hindsight. It is to the future that I must look now. Only I can see it, for the arrogant fool chose to share with me his 'genius'... However, his plan is perfect.

I can see the snuffing out of the light that was the once great empire of man... I can stop it.

For him I pretended to be bold and brave. I am no such thing. I am cowardly and paranoid. Though I cannot stop my life from draining away I can strike back from beyond the grave to ruin his carefully laid plains. You will be my tool. I only wish I could be there the moment his realise that is was his ego that defeated him.

reviewText:
I wrote several reviews about this game, this is my final. This is not a strict strategy game, its a MOBA+strategy, a hybrid. Its good only for 2v2 and 3v3 and that's what most players of this game play. Its well suited for Faction war meaning all 3 heroes of the same faction together in the same team fighting all the 3 heroes of another faction. Playing the game like that its fun so i recommend real life friends to get it as this is how i started this game. Dont get the game if you are to play it solo you wont have fun. It would be great if its campaign had 4 player cooperate instead of 2 so that's a big deal negative, if there is a patch  that makes coop campaign for 4 players that would be great. In general i only recommend to get this game if you have a real life premade team lets say or you plan to play it with online friends, its good for that.  DoW 2 Retribution is a poorly made mini CoH 1 and has nothing to do with Warhammer 40K. DoW 1 mods are WAY BETTER and are 40K SOLID. To a casual gamer i recommend this game, to someone who wants 40K no i dont. This is a review for both DoW 2 and DoW 2 Retribution. This game is over-simplified that's a major con of it.
BUT
There is a mod called The Elite mod which added more units to the game and rebalanced it to a much better degree than retail and added in its strategy value, so if it is to play  DoW 2 get Elite mod, it has way more SOLID gameplay.
Personally i dont like DoW 2 for it could have been WAY BETTER but this is my personal opinion, many other pro gamers like it and find it real fun to play.
Also there is another important feature of this game, the quotes, for every type of attack and direction of the attack a unit receives it quotes that attack so you know what it coming and from where and you can react fast and accurately, this is a great feature this game has. The game has very good graphic as well and it is beautiful. I dislike it cause of the gameplay meaning it COULD have been way better than it is, which is good still.

reviewText:
A fun game but also a downgrade from the original Dawn of War series in my opinion.

Here's why:

Improvements-
Better visuals
Dynamic cover
New units

Downgrades-
No base building; yes, I enjoyed building a base up as it gave the original Dawn of War series more tension as you had to keep your base operational to continue the mission, this.....not the same feeling
Individual units cost population cap (only ones I can accept are Orkz and Tyranids actually)
No separate population cap for vehicles
Campaign mission locations are the same for each race with little to no differences
Can't have a huge army
No Squiggoth or Bloodthirster, Great Unclean One is not a good replacement in my opinion
No Necrons (just kidding, but I do wish they had added them as a full race, same with the Tau)


Worst downgrade:
You have MANUALLY FIRE THE BANEBLADE'S CANNONS!

Aside from all that though.....7/10. Really fun game

reviewText:
Alright. Let me start out with saying that in this game, contrary to Dawn of War +expansions (All respect to those as they're plain awesome), you actually get the feel of the Hero type you choose, and you get that feeling of being totally BEE AYE. You get to integrate a Hero, such as (And one of my personal favorites!) the Inquisitor, into a full on battle, and at last those herotypes get the venerable strength and versatility they deserve according to the lore.

The gameplay itself, albeit lacking the whole base expansion thing as far as I've seen, as many other games got, this game makes up with it with on-the-go deployment whilst getting to fully fledge the units of yours into defensive postures much like the Company of Heroes style of games and you get to really unfold your tactical knowledge and strategic flair to their full extent, and put these to the test. So if you're a selfproclaimed master tactician, this is a game where you get to test it, without having humongous unconfined levels where the enemy can literally hide behind a bush and stay alive in that way. Not to mention, you get the opportunity of fielding your factions most devastative vehicles and infantry short of a full on exterminatus.

The graphics are good though at first a tad confusing overlay wise, but aside from smaller nitpickings, I love the setting the game sets for each individual map and the level of details compromising the rather blocky HUD.

In short: If you're in for a thrill and want to see some De&De up close, and get to feel like you're actually a commander in WH40K, this is the game for you.  Now have me excused while I go back to wreak more havoc on those xenos!

reviewText:
I think I played it enough to write a review.
First of the all the game is amazing, there are 6 races which you can play with in the Single player and these factions are:
The space marines, Chaos space marines, Imperial Guards, Orcs, Elder and finally the Tyranids.
The campaign doesn't change between the races, but every time although you go through the same places and fight vs the same enemies it is still really fun!.
Unlike in the previous games such as, Dawn of War: Soulstorm or Dawn of War 2 Chaos Rising, here you have 4 commanders which you control and you also construct an army but not a base, you get your units by capturing a beacon or barracks (depends on your race) and from there you can deply troops into the battlefield.

The multiplayer is pretty active, a few cutom games here and there and it seems like people can't stop playing in the last stand! (The last stand is that you group up with 2 more players and try to survive waves of enemies up to 20 waves)
The game also has many dlc's many of them are skins for the multiplayer or some wargear for the single player, except one DLC which is the Tau commander, that one DLC might be expensive, but if you really like the last stand which I mentioned above you might want to consider buying it. The DLC will give you a new commander to play with in the last stand and he is damn powerful, but as powerful as he is, it doesn't mean he is more powerful than the other commanders, he has his pros and cons.

Overall the game is amazing, the story is nice, really fun single player campaign and the multiplayer is active.

reviewText:
10/10 One of my most played games recorded. The story does continue like it should with some epic graphic cutscenes that surely don't disappoint. The main reason I rate this so high and recommend is due to the multiplayer/Last Stand

Multiplayer- The multiplayer is very fun, having a few different modes that you may play with several tiers of units that you must micro manage to get that advantage over your opponents, strategy is critical to your victory. Sacrificing 50 points just to create your most powerful unit to then turn the tide of battle is one of those decisions you may have to make.

Last Stand- Last stand is my favorite part of this game and is where most of my hours have gone. A strategic survival battle where you and 2 others last against many waves of enemies while using your unique skills which propose your role to the battle. Some are more AoE and taking out infantry where you may die fast, whereas some are bulky armored and focus more on the bigger tougher enemies on the battlefield.

reviewText:
Came from Dawn Of War, Stayed for Last Stand.

I think, over 70% of the people who play this game, came for a better version of the original Dawn Of War, but got disappointed. Personally, I love base building, and to find out that it was removed was a real kick in the teeth. I've played multiplayer with a group of friends on both games, and they all agree that this seems watered down due to the absense of base building, but agree that the game feels much nicer. One other thing that bothered us was how easy the game
seemed, even on harder difficulties. Yet, the original Dawn Of War is insane and very difficult.

However, Last Stand is amazing. I play with the same group, and we really enjoy the game. Currently, our go to game to waste time. Really enjoyable and for that, I'll rate this positive. Don't get me wrong, multiplayer is still okay but, not as good as the original.

I've played the campaign with a friend, and it's very good. We both enjoy the leveling system. I'm quite disappointed the fact you can't have 4 people, considering you control 4 heros and squads which can be real hard to micro manage each of their movements, especially since you have different roles like tanks and healers. Having 4 player campaign would be awesome. None the less I still enjoy the campaign.

reviewText:
I'm a little hesitant about recommending this, despite having enjoyed this game a lot.

I can definitely see a few problems about this game.

First one being that nobody plays the multiplayer anymore, so the best course of action is to also buy extra copies to give to friends for private multiplayer sessions.
Second problem being that if you play this game before playing Dawn of War 1, DoW1's gameplay will be ruined for you.
Aaaand the third problem: With THQ being dead, i'm concerned that a good chunk of that money will go to Games Workshop instead of Relic Entertainment.

The positive aspects of the game would definitely have to be the combat system. While traditional RTS fans will dislike the lack of base building, i felt that the combat system was pretty well done, with shrubs and small pieces of rubble providing cover for infantry, vehicles taking extra damage from behind, and infantry suppression from weapon platforms such as the heavy bolter. In addition to the gameplay, the campaign is really about as good as it can get despite all the campaigns using the same map.

Final verdict: While I believe that you should play this game if you have the slightest interest in Warhammer 40,000, wait for a bloody sale. Do you really want Games Workshop to earn 20 buxx for every copy of this game sold?

reviewText: This is a great action packed game with great graphics!  It has three game modes including single and co op campaign with 6 different races. The campaign can be set on easy, normal, hard and very hard.  The second game mode is multiplayer. You can also choose of 6 different races and their costume colors. You can do many different things on multiplayer, for e.g: 1v1, 2v2, 3v3 etc. But my personal favourite is Last Stand. You can choose out of 6 races (or 7 if you have dlc) and can the play on two different maps. You play with three different people and as you gain more experience you can make your character stronger by giving him armor, weapons, and traits and abilities. You should seriously think about getting this game!

reviewText:
Epic Battles!
This game is a RTS title that’s focussed on maintaining each and every unit you create.
I love this game because each skirmish or multiplayer game is an epic adventure from start to finish.

This game focuses allot more on the units rather than the base management. As soon as you start the game you are aggressively pushing forward and capturing resource points across the map. This style of play immediately puts you into the thick of it with the other player.  Which means fun right from the start!
The campaign is very different from the skirmish part. It’s more like a dungeon crawl RPG with hero units you and a friend can control that go all over the map using special abilities from equipment you pick up or skills that you learn when you level up. It’s actually really fun.
But this game shines on the multiplayer. The races are all very different and each race has 3 unique heroes than you take into battle.
I can easily recommend this game to any RTS fan. There is allot more to this game than I explained in this short review. You’ll have a blast finding out all the different game modes.

reviewText: I really do like this game. the last stand and multiplayer are very enjoyable indeed. Last Stand is where you choose a hero (ork, space marine, chaos, imperial guard or  tyranid) and you try to last as long as you can against hordes of enimies that get increasingly difficult. The multiplayer is where you fight against other people online. All fine and dandy... but then there's the campaign. In the campaign you choose from any of the five races (the same ones from the Last Stand) and work your way through a story (obviously) and you give your heroes better armour, weapons etc. The only problem is all of the campaigns are pretty much the same except for dialogue, troops and the race that you are. Though the campaign is kind of fun when you play with a friend.\n\nSo it's a pretty good game over all and I enjoy it. But if you're looking for replayability on a campaign and that's all you want give it a miss. But if you don't care about that play it for multiplayer and Last Stand because they are really fun!

The Cons:

Overall great game.

reviewText:
This reveiw is only about the multiplayer experience.
Dawn of War 2:Retribution could have beenthe best rts game ever made. It offers 6 factions, each faction has 3 commanders and each commander can have 1 or 2 different playstyles, including wargear that you can buy for them to make them more adaptable to different situations, so the game has a lot of variety in playstyle.
But the game still has some flaws, flaws that would have probably been fixed by THQ if they didnt shut down. For example the game can be pretty imbalanced in some matchups, for example chaos vs imperial guard, where the IG need to rush to tier 3 as fast as possible because every single tier 1 and tier 2 unit that the chaos forces ahve outclass the IG variant, the game is still fun though if you get a fair matchup, and i heard that the elite mod adressess a lot of balance issues and its pretty popular amongst the community, so if you dont like the base or get bored of it and want something else then you still have a good choice.
Overall the game is still pretty good in its current state, its not a bad game, it can be a lot of fun at times, but it could be so much more, i wish relic would still bring new stuff to this game like they do with company of heroes, but if you are looking for a good strategy game in one of the most interesting settings in video game history, then this game might be what you need.

reviewText:
If you are coming from the plethora of Dawn of War games before then you are well prepared for this installation of Dawn of War: Retribution.

I won't lie, if you are here for the campaign, it is fairly dull. There are 6 factions to play. They include: Space Marines, Orks, Eldar, Tyranids, Imperial Guard, and Chaos Space Marines. The campaign takes place in a galaxy with numerous planets, representing your possible missions and various rewards. Your army consists of a couple heroes that carry over gamer after game and which you can level up and acquire new and better gear for. Playing through the campaign once is not bad. However, it is pretty much the same for each factions, meaning it will get repetetive after one or two walkthroughs.

Don't want the campaign? How about skirmish against the AI to test your skills. It heavily revolves around controlling objectives to gain points and power to build your armies. The biggest downfall of the game was base building though. You start the game with one building. It's your command center that is responsible for spawning all your troops and researching all the tech. The goal of the match is to destroy the enemy HQ. It has a lot of HP and it takes more advanced troops to finally put it down. I have to say that I enjoy base building like Dawn of War Soulstorm had so this game was dissapointing.

Multiplayer is largely as described above, just against players.

What I really found fun in this game was Arena mode, also called The Last Stand. You can actually purchase it as a sepparate game and avoid paying the Full Price all together.

The Last Stand mode lets you pick your general. They all start with level 1 and level up until 20, with each level granting them unique weapons, armors, and abilities. Your general is then taken to an arena (currently 2 variants) with 2 other players and left to survive 20 waves. Each wave throws various galactic abominations at you from all different factions and your only purpose is th survive".

So
date:
can you?


All in all. It's not a bad game. Graphics are alright and the campaign is good for 1-2 run throughs
recommended: the last stand mode is a lot of fun
hoursPlayed: and multiplayer is action packed. I would definitelly play this game at least once for the experience

reviewText:
I wrote a multi-page review for this and maxed out steam's review system. So let me give you the basic version.

This is a strategy game with more replayability than any other RTS I have seen. This is a game where you create something truly unique and generate your own personal play style and due to the unbelievably well made balance in this game, it will actually work. This is a game with multipe game modes that can cater to ANY type of strategy player, and enough customization to have the army that looks exactly the way you want it to. This will cater to fans of classic RTS games, tactical RTT games, and even MOBA and other action-RPG games with ease. Get it for yourself, get it for your friends, and enjoy one of the greatest RTS games ever created in a standalone expansion that gives you EVERYTHING - regardless of whether you have the original Dawn of War 2 or not.

GET THIS GAME. NOW.

reviewText:
I like this game. A lot. I like the theme/setting of the game. This is particularly ironic because, as a player of tabletop wargames, I do not like the Warhammer 40k tabletop setting at all. But in this video game, the factions and their units look and play great.

I've touched the campaign and looked at last stand, but I really spent my time in this game doing multiplayer (1v1, 2v2, 3v3, TFFA, and, always to my everlasting displeasure, annihilation).

I like how this game is not about base-building and sending unit after unit off to die on the battlefield. It's about keeping units, and improving units. Because of the time you spend with your guys, this game is about loving your units. It's great to see that Guardian squad that I started the match with 18 minutes later, rolling with the support of a Warlock, embolded,  and dropping effective grenades in the late game. Or that Banshee squad who even after seeing some extremely close, close calls thoughout the match and coming within just a few hit points of an untimely death, regrouped and putting the hurts on a dreadnought in the late game. But not everyone can survive, and when you lose a unit the pain is real! You find yourself giving micro-eulogies to your fallen squads, thanking them for thier contribution to the effort and reminding them that it was, hopefully, not in vain.

This is the aspect of the game that I like the most. But there are other cool things. I like that there are asymetrical maps (just like on my tabletop). I like how the hero characters (I've only play Eldar>Warlock) work in the game's mechanics. I like the suppression weapon platforms and how they work with arcs and set-up/break-down timers.

I really like the timing of the game. I like how you have time to flank a turtling Techmarine who hides behind his too-many-turrets. Or how you can chose to just ignore his turret spam until you get to Tech level II and address it then. There's plenty of other places to attack. (Oh, how many times have I seen poor players, including my noob-self, continuing to attempt to push into turrets and pay the full cost for the choice when it could have addressed later?)

Anyway. those are somethings I like about this game. I guess I paid $60 for this game when it came out and I've played for over 1500 hours, so that's less than 4 cents per hour. You can't beat that with a D-Cannon.

reviewText:
Warhammer 40k DoW II is a moba like twist on the beloved origonal DoW franchise, for some it will be a welcome change, for others a turning point to other games.

As an fan of the old DoW game / expansions i found that this was a wierd yet intriguing change for me, the game focuses less on base building (all you can build is generators and you can upgrade your main base, thats it) and focuses more on the constant exchanging of forces and holding capture points.

For people who are used to the general combat of games like Star Craft II this will be similar to how you DoW II runs with no base building and a focus on controlling points. the big focus for this game is control and managing your units effectivly. this can be appealing to some and off putting for others

this expansion / all in one game is better than DoW II itself and id say just get this as it adds more units and another storyline (which isnt amazing but works)

so in general i would say if you want the old DoW game then give this a skip, but if you want a Warhammer 40k game similar to Star Craft II then id say go for it


Disclaimer
**i have played Star Craft II, im no pro or anything and i dont know 100% what im talking about so this is just a general view i can give and comparision from to 80+ hours ive played**

reviewText:
The Emperor Protects, and this title does the Emperor proud indeed. Unless, of course, you are a filthy Heretic and thus must be purged.

Gameplay is very similar to the Company of Heroes titles in the sense that the game plays in a very arcade-y feel. If you're expecting this Dawn of War to be similar to the earlier Dawn of War titles, you would be quite disappointed.

That is not to say the game itself is bad, it is anything but. The voice acting and atmosphere of the game really hammers (hehe) in the feeling of the Warhammer 40k franchise, and does the respective factions in the game alot of justice.

The multiplayer is active, albeit slightly small, but is engaging and fun nonetheless.
Dawn of War II: Retribution gives the franchise a great name, and I can't recommend this game enough to 40k fans, new and old.

Emperor guide you, my friends.

reviewText:
Is it an ok game to pass a few hours on? well just look at the hours ive put in should tell you something.

Having said that can I recommend it now? probably not.

Whilst it's a fine game and deceptive simple looking it contains a heap of good strategy, some solid modes like the arena game, a good enough campaign though not as good as DOW 1's but it's the multiplayer that lets the game down in the end. When and if you do find a match you're going to run into the same issues Company of heroes 2 has in that your rarely going to get a game where not one person drops, robbing all players regardless of time played of their exp. Most do it out of spite, some just drop right at the start leaving you with a mess of a match as the ill equipped AI take over just goes around capping everything removing any fun or strategy from the game. Rarely have I enjoyed a good online match and 90% you will be met with nothing but frustration as players rage quit right at the end of the match to rob everyone of their rightful exp. The multiplayer is seriously flawed for this reason with no punishment system in place this will keep happening.

For those reasons even though I had fun for a while I can't in all honesty recommend it to someone looking for a good experience either single player or multiplayer. Even for 40k fans there's games out there that do it far better at the end of the day.

reviewText:
The missions seemed bland and formulaic - Drop in, go somewhere, shoot things along the way, fight a boss once you reach the end. Occasionally this is broken up by the mission prodding you along (the infamous BEHNBLADE), or having to deal with fortified strongpoints.

The gameplay itself actually seemed weaker than the previous DoW II titles - While it's still a very unit-centric squad-based RTT, there's a lot more units available to you and on the field in general, each with their own properties. Normally I wouldn't complain about having a lot to keep track of, but micro-heavy gameplay like slotting your infantry into good cover and placing/orienting heavy weapons squads works best when you're dealing with smaller forces rather than larger ones. This is especially amplified by the general trend towards smaller engagements; Fairly frequently, I'd be cramming 40 guardsmen into a space meant for a dozen Space Marines.

Basic encounters tended to feel chaotic, but not urgent - Lots to keep track of, but not a whole lot on the line.

Boss fights rapidly became repetitive. The nature of them, one at the end of every level, plus the limited unit selection brought about by 40k armies meant that, fairly often, I'd be fighting yet *another* Hive Tyrant, except this time in a jungle-themed arena rather than a gothic cathedral-themed one.

Honestly, I think Chaos Rising is a lot stronger than Retribution, simply because it's closer to the overall design of the series. Retribution has a lot more units on the field to play around with, but Dawn of War 2 isn't a game that's designed for that and it shows.

Is this a good game? It is... It's fun, and fast paced... But I feel like it didn't capture the feel of the original dawn of war, due to the fact that they COMPLETELY take away the base building, which is something in RTS's I enjoy. However, I'm going to base this review in the style I did for the first Dawn of War, Speaking from a die hard Warhammer fan.

Let's go over the positives of this game...
-The action and pathing are improved, You are stuck right into it. and the fights are fun to watch.
-The Voice acting in this game, is superb. And Very well done.
-The campaign is very well made, However, this also contains a flaw, which I'll go over.
-Multiplayer play is quite well, and still has multple game types, like the first Dawn of war game.
-Each unit has to be treated like the table top counter part, such as, some are expendable, but if you keep losing too much, you will lose. Which has an immersion factor for me.
-The soundtrack... Oh My God... The soundtrack for this game, is probably one of the best I've heard...
-The developers added attention to detail, and added unit cries and announcer cries that differ depending on what race you are going against. for example, If you play orks, and then order an attack on an eldar, they might say something like Eldar ar da squishiest.." reviewText:
9/10

Retribution is the second and last expansion pack of Dawn of War II, and between the three games which compose the II storyline, Retribution is most certainly my favorite. It possesses all the content of the previous two games, updated with the inclusion of the Imperial Guard faction alongside new units for every race. These include superheavy units for each race, and now your Space Marines, Orks and Tyranids will have something to fight those pesky Avatars of Khaine and Great Unclean Ones with the addition of Land Raiders, Ork Battlewagons, the Swarmlord himself and the Imperial Guard's newly arrived Baneblade.

Retribution has its own campaign which serves as a conclusion for the storyline of not only Dawn of War II and Chaos Rising, but also for Dawn of War I and its own expansion packs. All that has happened in the games' storyline has led up to this game, and you have the opportunity to play as any of the races in the campaign. While the campaign is repetitive (all races share the same missions and overall story), it is nonetheless enjoyable to go around defeating armies of daemons with irish Ork space pirate captains.

Retribution also wins because it has the best voice acting. Everyone has a british accent. EVERYONE.

IN THE GRIM DARKNESS OF THE FUTURE, EVERYONE IS BRITISH.

AND I LOVE IT.

reviewText: Dawn of War II? Moar like Dawn of War II, III and IV, amirite? Okay, it's not that huge, but it can make for really fun times, and really does happen to be more like three games than just one.  You've got the campaigns which play out as an action RPG. In Vanilla and Chaos Rising, you follow the exploits of a group of Blood Raven Space Marines, super soldiers out to save the day and stuffs. Retribution here lets you pick any of the factions available in the game for your campaign. The single-player/co-op is a lot like a Dungeon Siege style of RPG, where you get to handle squad leaders with ability points and items as you level up. Multiplayer is a fast paced RTS, with matches that last around 30 minutes and jump into the thick of it, without having to worry about base building at all. Lastly, The Last Stand. It's a game on its own. Play as heroes, and team up with others to survive waves of mooks. It's as fun as it is nightmarishly addicting. So yup. That's all, folks!

reviewText:
Wooooooooot

So I've decided to make this a proper review.

Let's get straight to the point. DoW2, much like it's predecessor, is a RTS set in the grimdark world of Warhammer 40,000. Unlike its predecessor however, your battles are on a far smaller scale. No longer do you have a huge squad of 9 marines per squad for example. Nor can you build more than one Land Raider. Instead squad sizes are far smaller(unless you're 'nids or orks in which case numbers wins the day), and focused more on flanking, tactics, special abilities and the like. In my opinion this actually makes the game more enjoyable for me. DoW1 felt too much like any stereotypical RTS wearing a 40k skin. DoW2 feels unique.

The campaign is basically an adventure, with a neat story, neat gear and the like. Done with campaign and bored of it? RTS battles await. Don't want to play it as a RTS? Last Stand. For a game that is this old now, there's plenty to see and do. If you're a 40k fan, then every now and then it's great to get your 40k kicks in.

DoW2 Retribution is perhaps the last great 40k game. None of those released after it so far has been anywhere as epic a journey. Until Sega decides to make a DoW3, this game above all else, is probably THE 40k PC game I'd choose if I had to pick one to play for the rest of my life.

And I guess it'd be remiss not to mention that I'm massively into 40k today only because of this game.

reviewText: Well, this is a RTS. It is played in the dark universe of 40k and feature 6 factions. Bio engineered superhumans with freaking 200kg armours, normal humans that loves tanks, deamon worshipping humans with horns and spikes, squishy and fast eldars, orks that lives for fighting and the tyranids who eats everything. you simply choose one of these factions and head straight into multiplayer. i wouldnt bother going campaign without a friend (atleast after finishing it 5 times with each faction). each faction has 3 characters who each offers a different field presence and supporting abilities. in this you have to look out for your units, and micromanaging is the way to win. this does not give you the oppurtunity to build bases as in the first game, and the units are way smaller, but the effects are better and the randomness of melee is always fun. the real problem is that it doesnt have a huge community, and so not many games are up. for the really great experiance and balance of the game, simply get elite mod. fast to doenload and enhances the gameplay alot. reviewText:
Two very simple points.

1. Campaign is bad. All of them lack the depth of the original Dawn of War 2, and its expansion: Chaos Rising.

All of the in game races are available to play. But in expense all of them are short and are copy and paste versions of each other.

2. Multiplayer is amazing. Great maps, great balance and overall the best multiplayer experience of any of the Dawn of War 2 games.

Last Stand is equally amazing. Unlockables, leveling, customization. Probably one of the best horde modes I've ever played

In conclusion, If you're looking to buy this game for its single player, go look somewhere else, but if you're looking for an amazing Warhammer 40,000 multiplayer experience then you've come to the right game.

reviewText:
Is this a good game? It is... It's fun, and fast paced... But I feel like it didn't capture the feel of the original dawn of war, due to the fact that they COMPLETELY take away the base building, which is something in RTS's I enjoy. However, I'm going to base this review in the style I did for the first Dawn of War, Speaking from a die hard Warhammer fan.

Let's go over the positives of this game...
-The action and pathing are improved, You are stuck right into it. and the fights are fun to watch.
-The Voice acting in this game, is superb. And Very well done.
-The campaign is very well made, However, this also contains a flaw, which I'll go over.
-Multiplayer play is quite well, and still has multple game types, like the first Dawn of war game.
-Each unit has to be treated like the table top counter part, such as, some are expendable, but if you keep losing too much, you will lose. Which has an immersion factor for me.
-The soundtrack... Oh My God... The soundtrack for this game, is probably one of the best I've heard...
-The developers added attention to detail, and added unit cries and announcer cries that differ depending on what race you are going against. for example, If you play orks, and then order an attack on an eldar, they might say something like Eldar ar da squishiest.." Capturing the humor and immersion of the Warhammer universe.
-To make the game more strategic
recommended: So choosing your units contains strategy to it.\n-The last stand mode is really fun
hoursPlayed:
and it's a great idea. Holding off hordes of enemies with other players controlling your character is quite immersive.

That's the positive aspects of this game... now for the negative.

reviewText:
A wonderful RTS which focuses on managing fewer units and forgoes base building and large scale macromanagement. Oozes 40k charm with each unit, with multiplayer and singleplayer offering both a quality experiance and with massive replayability.

Buy it if you have any interest in warhammer 40k, buy it if you like RTS or Company of Heroes, buy it because decent Warhammer games need your cashbucks to thrive.

If you already own this game play it more, the fantastic Elite mod offers continual support and its sheer accessibility means you can get good games going very quickly. The wall of inaccessability which hobbles most RTS is absent here, allowing games against even experianced players to go either way with the right choices - rather than build orders and meta gaming dictating the outcome before the game even begins.

Probably the best Warhammer game out there, and it deserves your attention.

reviewText:
Wooooooooot

So I've decided to make this a proper review.

Let's get straight to the point. DoW2, much like it's predecessor, is a RTS set in the grimdark world of Warhammer 40,000. Unlike its predecessor however, your battles are on a far smaller scale. No longer do you have a huge squad of 9 marines per squad for example. Nor can you build more than one Land Raider. Instead squad sizes are far smaller(unless you're 'nids or orks in which case numbers wins the day), and focused more on flanking, tactics, special abilities and the like. In my opinion this actually makes the game more enjoyable for me. DoW1 felt too much like any stereotypical RTS wearing a 40k skin. DoW2 feels unique.

The campaign is basically an adventure, with a neat story, neat gear and the like. Done with campaign and bored of it? RTS battles await. Don't want to play it as a RTS? Last Stand. For a game that is this old now, there's plenty to see and do. If you're a 40k fan, then every now and then it's great to get your 40k kicks in.

DoW2 Retribution is perhaps the last great 40k game. None of those released after it so far has been anywhere as epic a journey. Until Sega decides to make a DoW3, this game above all else, is probably THE 40k PC game I'd choose if I had to pick one to play for the rest of my life.

And I guess it'd be remiss not to mention that I'm massively into 40k today only because of this game.

reviewText:
If you enjoy 1v1 in RTS, you will probably like Dawn of War II: Retribution. The game averages about 2000+ active people per day. Most of them probably do 1v1 games. There is a rather steep learning curve if you are used to Starcraft because you no longer have to build a base. You have to claim requisition points and power nodes to purchase stronger squads or upgrade your fortress to unlock the next tier of units.

Strategically, this game is king because it has you thinking throughout the entire match about where to position yourself on the map.

I'd have to give it a 7.5/10 because the company hasn't been too active in updating a few things that this game needs. If your computer is fast but your opponents computer is slow, the game tries too hard to make it slow for everyone... until that player drops. When a player drops, the AI takes control of him.

reviewText: Dawn Of War II Retribution Takes place in the Warhammer 40,000 universe, a milky way galaxy filled with xenos, daemons and super soldiers called Space Marines. It has a campaign for all 6 playable races the Eldar, Chaos Space Marines, Imperial Guard, Space Marines, Tyranids, and Orks. My personal rating of this game is a 9 out of 10 because a few things seem overly powerful, but other than that this game is very balanced. reviewText: Dawn of War II has a really interesting universe. The campaign in this game clearly shows love for the Space Marine faction, every other campaign seems tacked on and unimportant. The graphics are good, as well as the sound design. The Strategy elements are well done. It's the same engine as Company of Heroes, so it basically plays the same as that game, however the engine feels a little bit better in this type of universe. The game is definitely geared towards multiplayer, but the its either a hit or miss. The mechanics of the game are easily fustrating in a game of poor connections and none of the strategic elements are clear enough to know what's what. Counters are hard to learn on your own, as well as build orders and proper micro's. There are a good community of players geared toward helping players imrpove their game, but if you not totally invested into the game's stats and numbers for every unit prepared to get scraped over and over again because the player base is 75% veteran.

reviewText: Well, this is a RTS. It is played in the dark universe of 40k and feature 6 factions. Bio engineered superhumans with freaking 200kg armours, normal humans that loves tanks, deamon worshipping humans with horns and spikes, squishy and fast eldars, orks that lives for fighting and the tyranids who eats everything. you simply choose one of these factions and head straight into multiplayer. i wouldnt bother going campaign without a friend (atleast after finishing it 5 times with each faction). each faction has 3 characters who each offers a different field presence and supporting abilities. in this you have to look out for your units, and micromanaging is the way to win. this does not give you the oppurtunity to build bases as in the first game, and the units are way smaller, but the effects are better and the randomness of melee is always fun. the real problem is that it doesnt have a huge community, and so not many games are up. for the really great experiance and balance of the game, simply get elite mod. fast to doenload and enhances the gameplay alot. BLOOD FOR THE BLOOD GOD! SKULLS FOR THE SKULL THRONE! LET THE GALAXY BURN!

reviewText: A strong RTS placed in the brutal Warhammer Universe, Dawn of War: Retribution is another successful game by Relic Studios. Focusing on smaller scale units, Retribution invests the player into each individual platoon of troops. Each faction offers a unique selection of heroes, units, and buildings that make each campaign a slightly different affair. The heroes are easily the main draw and will be the “go to” unit for each battle, ensuring their usage as an important focus for the game. The story and the cinematic are excellent with the bleakness of the Warhammer Universe conveyed with a meaty narrative. The replayablilty of the game suffers slightly, as the levels tend to not be different enough to warrant more than a few play-through. Overall, Dawn of War: Retribution is a solid RTS game that is well worth the purchase if you enjoy crushing heathens in the name of the Emperor.
