reviewText:
Dawn of War II: Retribution is a superbly made Real-Time Strategy game. Each player has a HQ from which they build units. Unlike a lot of strategy games, Retribution does not require the player to build structures to train units and gather resources. Rather, you start the game off with your choice of 1 of 3 of your chosen factions hero, as well as the basic infantry type of your faction. Then, to gather resources you command your units to capture Requisition (the main resource used for everything) and Power (a secondary resource for purchasing more advanced units and upgrading your units and their tech as well as researching the next tier) points. For each point you capture, the amount of Requistion/Power you earn per second increases. The only disappointment i have with all of the Dawn of War games is the very limited unit cap of 100.
Don't let that stop you from getting this amazing game, perfect for new players and RTS veterans!

Jester's Rating: 8.5/10

reviewText:
Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II: Retribution. The third and most likely the final entry for the Dawn of War II franchise steers clear of its predecessors.
The game introduces to us a new set of campaign introducing the might of the Imperial Guard that evolves into six different races yet in the same planetary sector giving you six point of view.
Relic took a new approach to the game by no longer implementing the Hero Squads in the campaign and emphasizes more on its Multiplayer based squads that definitely tells you what Relic is known best for. With a new gameplay system that steers in a different direction from vanilla Dow2/CR, Retribution is definitely worth your money at sales price.

Pros:
- New Super Heavy Units that spice things up in Skirmish/PVP mode.
- Imperial Guard :0
- More stuffs in The Last Stand Mode
- No more Games for Windows Live.
- Elite Mod developed by talented individuals bringing even more stuff :D (Google it)

Cons:
- The game is no longer supported by Relic but still is playable online.
- Sketchy matchmaking system.
- Campaign is a little bit or more recycled for all the races.
- F*ck You GFWL.

reviewText:
DOWII retribution is without comparison one of the best looking, and most strategically interesting strategy game out there.
This stand alone expansion fixes the vast majority of balance issues posed by end game battles in previous games.
The game is first and foremost a multiplayer upgrade, the campaigs for all races are all the same with very minor differences, the storylines are non-existent for most races and all campaigns are designed to be won without trying.
Still, with the underwhelming graphics and multiplayer of strarcraft 2, dow2:R still holds the RTS genere firmly in its grasp

reviewText:
TLDR – Dawn of War 2 Retribution is a standalone Real Time Strategy game following the events of Warhammer 40k Dawn of War 2 and its DLC Chaos Rising.  This time around you actually get to manage some resources and build a few units instead of just commanding a team of heroes.

I didn’t play Chaos Rising, and a bunch of stuff apparently happened in the story so I wasn’t sure of the timeline on starting Retribution (the stories are pretty much completely unrelated). Fortunately, the plot is cohesive and you should be able to follow it if you have basic knowledge of the Warhammer 40k universe. Note that despite the fact that there are 6 different races to play in Retribution, they all have pretty much the same story. Space Marine, Chaos Space Marine, Eldar, Ork, Tyranid, and Imperial Guard all play the same series of missions just with slight changes to the narration. Basically, no matter which team you’re on, you need to stop a bad guy from ascending to demon form before an Imperial extermination force wipes out the entire star sector.

If you’ve played Real Time Strategy Games like Starcraft, Warcraft, or Command & Conquer, you should be able to pick up Retribution’s gameplay almost immediately. But instead of building a base and harvesting resources, you start each level with hero units and need to work your way across the map while claiming resource “nodes” and command points. Do you remember the “commando” missions from Starcraft where you need to get your hero through the level relying on special powers while occasionally having backup appear? Well the whole game of Retribution is like that. The enemy is already entrenched in each level, and each of your hero units has special abilities gained through level ups and / or special items (war gear). The war gear is randomly dropped during gameplay and equipped between missions. So beating the game is mostly about managing your energy (mana) for using special powers and not biting off more than you can chew at once.

The game has a cover system where if you move near certain items on the map like buildings or busted up walls, your units will attempt to hide behind them for a defense bonus, but honestly with so many special powers flying around, the cover isn’t as important as blasting the enemy before he blasts you. Make sure you diversify the equipment and special powers of your team and take your time with each level. You will find the game is not very difficult, especially if you’re playing as the Tyranid race. The Tyranids seem to be unique in that you only get one hero in the campaign (but that hero is seriously badass). Along with your hero units, you have the opportunity to requisition additional units at command points throughout each level. These units are obviously much weaker than your heroes but you can build up a nice army and flank enemy positions. The army will never be too big due to the population cap, but it does make finishing each level easier.

Pros:
+Fun game and not very punishing for casual gamers.  It’s pretty hard to actually lose, I don’t think I failed even one level. It just takes patience for your energy to recharge before you assault fortified enemy positions.
+There is some variety in gameplay. Like the original Dawn of War 2, your units mostly have both melee and ranged attacks and you can gear up your units with particular equipment to enhance your play style. With 6 different playable races you shouldn’t be surprised to find that you’re occasionally fighting each of the six races throughout your campaign.
+There are still people playing the game online if multiplayer is what you’re into. When I played there were usually about 300 other players though I didn’t really interact with them. I did try the Last Stand gameplay mode which is a 3 person co-op vs waves of enemies (took about 2-3 minutes to set up each match). I didn’t get very far but it seems to be the kind of game mode where you keep playing to level up, and hence get further and further along. Yes, there is also a co-op campaign mode.

Cons:
-Like the original Dawn of War 2, there are a ton of Steam achievements that seem tied to multiplayer. If you’re mostly into single player story campaigns like me, you’ll beat the game with less than 20% achievements and bring down your overall stats :(
-As I mentioned before, all the races essentially have the same campaign. This makes the game surprisingly short and you can be done with it in about 2 days. No point in continuously replaying the same missions unless you’re grinding for achievements.

Overall the game is fun if you’re into real time strategy or the Warhammer universe. If you have a friend to play co-op or Last Stand mode with, even better. Just note that getting far in Last Stand will require a significant time investment. There’s not much luck and skill involved until higher waves, and to get there you need to be high level.  And again, if you’re playing the single player campaign as Tyranid, play it in Hard or Very Hard difficulty mode unless it’s your very first time playing a real time strategy game. They’re just too strong for normal difficulty if you focus on ranged warriors.

reviewText:
The new (now old) DoW 2 : Retribution is a very beautiful looking game. Graphics are very good, gameplay is somewhere in between good and bad. When comes to Single Player/Campaign game is actually really good, it's a mix of RPG and strategy. You can build and customize your heros and armies and play in interesting linear campaign missions. Also a good thing to say, is that you can experience same story from angle of total 6 races, bad side is that all 6 races have same identical missions, only different is final goal. So once you complete campaign with one race, you have seen it all. But DoW 2 and expanision shine in Campaign gameplay but are total let down when comest to multiplayer and skirmish against AI.

As an old player of DoW: Soulstorm, multiplayer game experience was mix of huge armies and building a bases all over the map. DoW2 and this Retributin expansion offers you a small scale battles (in true meaning of word skirmishes ). You will lead maybe a 4 or 5 units max at the time, there is no base building, every unit comes from one building, which means you can't build two different units at the same time, which slows gamelplay drastically. Resaurces are scarce.

Pros:
Campaign
Graphics
Single Player gameplay

Cons:
No base building
Training one unit at the time
Scarce resources
Small battles
Training both vehicles and units of all types from one single building.

My Recommendation:
Buy it for campaign and good looks, but for real and better 40k experience buy DoW:Soulstorm or Dark Crusade.
So first DoW + expansions for MultiPlayer and DoW2 + expansions for SinglePlayer (Campaign)

reviewText:
Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II Retribution is a real-time strategy/tactical role-playing video game developed by Relic Entertainment and published by THQ for Microsoft Windows based on the fictional Warhammer 40,000 universe. It is the sequel to the Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War video game series. Dawn of War II features a non-linear interplanetary campaign, as the Space Marines. The campaign can be played either as single-player or cooperatively with another player through an online connection.

The game's campaign departs from those of its predecessors in several key features. One of the most notable departures is that there are no base-building elements, unlike in previous Dawn of War titles. Instead, the player chooses the units to be used prior to beginning a mission, cannot build new units once the mission begins, and has only limited reinforcement options.

Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II – Retribution is the stand-alone second expansion to Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II, part of the Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War series of real-time strategy computer games. Set in Games Workshop's Warhammer 40,000 fictional universe, the single player campaign is playable with multiple races.

Imperial Guard is introduced as a new race, and all races including the races from the original game and the first expansion (the Eldar, the Space Marines, Chaos, the Orks and the Tyranids) are now playable in single-player and multiplayer.

Dawn of War II: Retribution offers a campaign for every race, including the Imperial Guard. The campaign takes place across different planets in Sub-sector Aurelia, including the jungle world Typhon Primaris, the desert world Calderis, the arctic world Aurelia, the hive world Meridian, the derelict ship Judgment of Carrion, and the dead world Cyrene.

reviewText: Warhammer 40, 000: Dawn of War 2 Retribution is a completely different game from the other 40k RTS's. This one focuses more on squad combat and strategy, rather than whoever gets the biggest army (maybe) or whoever rushes first. There is no more base building, which is kind of a disappointment but not a huge deal breaker. There is a single campaign that you can go through with the six races (Eldar, Tyranid, Space Marine, Imperial Guard, Orks, and Chaos). The part about it that makes me the most sad is that they removed the Necrons and the Tau as if they never existed. Again, not a huge deal breaker. You can get the Shas'O Commander in The Last Stand gametype as DLC, but that's the extent of it. The Last Stand is basically a horde mode consisting of you and two others. I am not kidding when I say it is pretty damn hard and evidently takes some getting used to. The community seems nice enough as well.\n\nThis is a great game with improved graphics, physics, and well, it's Warhammer 40k. What more could you ask for?

reviewText: Retribution follows up the story events of Chaos Rising, and then allows you to play a number of different single-player campaigns as each of the different playable races. Unlike in Winter Assault however, the campaigns here are... pretty much the same thing everytime without any real difference between the races. This is one of those games where multiplayer was the chief focus, and the Last Stand" Mode actually can be kinda fun if you can manage to get some people together who know what they are doing.\n\nAs for me
recommended: it's just one more grindy multiplayer experience vying for my attention... and I have WAY too many of those as is.\n\nI'll give this a "yes" because it does not do anything wrong per se

reviewText:
For a price of 30.00, this is worth the buy

Its a refreshing breath that even old games can still pack a punch of revolutionizing an RTS. Take a break from the micro and macro intensive Starcraft series, and enter a squad based Strategy / RPG which contains quite alot of bang for your Buck

Campaign: you can play as each of the six unqiue factions, The Holy Astartes, The Rowdy Orks, The Sneaky Eldar, The Spooky Chaos, and the numberless Imperial Guard and Tyranids. Although Story wise it isnt that good, and each campaign is around 5 hours if you speed run it, it can still be fun to play all six of them, already making 30 hours of playtime, and unlocking quite alot of achievements

Multiplayer: Probably the best aspect of the game, it is recommended you buy this game with a friend (Not many people play this game as it used to be, remember its old)

Last Stand: A CO-OP You can have blasts of fun blasting enemies into bits, and level up your hero to get new wargear

Overall, a good buy.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Dawn of War 2 and DoW2: Chaos Rising made a vast departue from the original Dawn of War games, going from a grand scale RTS similar to Command and Conquer to a squad-focused action-strategy game (for want of a better term). Retribution tries to marry the two, giving you a four-man team of hero units to work with and providing the option to exchange them for less-complicated but weaker elite squads before deployment or even calling in larger forces on the field (back to the DoW classic formula, albeit with perhaps fewer unit choices, particularly in the vehicular department).

But honestly, the hero units (and/or their elite squad replacements) are usually enough to complete most missions by themselves. Where DoW was like the equivalent of a standard game of tabletop Warhammer 40K, DoW2: Retribution is more like playing a game of Kill Team. In fact, if you're planning to buy the Kill Team game on Steam, don't bother; just buy this instead.

Also, the Last Stand multiplayer mode is super-fun. It's probably dead nowadays, but if you can get into an active server or have a few friends with the game, give it a go!

9/10 it okay, not subtle or nuanced but it okay

reviewText:
The surviving RTS game in this world, and it still stands out as a great game.

Pros:
+ Great variety of units
+ Races are interesting and beautifully crafted (Tyranids, holy mother of god, these reminds me of Godzilla)
+ In-Depth strategy
+ The leveling system of units, though some don't like it, I say it is a good system to employ so that players don't just command his/her units aimlessly.
+ Last Stand is a great alternative game mode. It reminds me of RPG games, with strategy sprinkle onto it. (E.g. Demigod)
++ No other game allows you customize your units' color.

Cons
- Campaign. It reminds me of CnC4, a bit short, and a bit unnecessary. Wish it was the DOW I Dark Crusade's style of campaign.
- Sometimes, units will not activate their skills. (Hive Tyrant's Bio Plasma, for example. He will stand there even though you issued the command.)
- Seemed that spamming range units is better than melee units. Melee units are a bit underpowered in this game in my opinion.

Overall, it's a great game. I hope that the RTS genre will survive in this MMORPG-ruled universe.

reviewText: A game that will test your reasoning as well as your skill. If you are looking for a strategy game that is not a clickfest and does not reward APM this is the one. Think of it like a CoH with melee! The single player experience is a bit stale and monotonous, but the multiplayer is fun and addictive. Sadly the playerbase is a bit small compared to, say, Starcraft 2, and the online community is more than a little harsh with noobies. And don't get the damn Elite mod, it only contributes to further reduce the playerbase and it's mostly smoke and mirrors!

reviewText:
It all started when our protagonist, Civ 5, woke up in a pumpkin patch. It was the fourth time it had happened. Feeling ridiculously exasperated, Civ 5 groped a sock, thinking it would make him feel better (but as usual, it did not). Unexpectedly, he realized that his beloved ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth was missing! Immediately he called his friend, Leroy Jenkins. Civ 5 had known Leroy Jenkins for (plus or minus) one million years, the majority of which were sassy ones. Leroy Jenkins was unique. He was intelligent though sometimes a little... dimwitted. Civ 5 called him anyway, for the situation was urgent.

Leroy Jenkins picked up to a very happy Civ 5. Leroy Jenkins calmly assured him that most koalas yawn before mating, yet otters usually earnestly grimace *after* mating. He had no idea what that meant; he was only concerned with distracting Civ 5. Why was Leroy Jenkins trying to distract Civ 5? Because he had snuck out from Civ 5's with the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth only four days prior. It was a saucy little ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth... how could he resist?

It didn't take long before Civ 5 got back to the subject at hand: his ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. Leroy Jenkins sighed. Relunctantly, Leroy Jenkins invited him over, assuring him they'd find the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. Civ 5 grabbed his desk and disembarked immediately. After hanging up the phone, Leroy Jenkins realized that he was in trouble. He had to find a place to hide the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth and he had to do it thoughtfully. He figured that if Civ 5 took the truck, he had take at least eleven minutes before Civ 5 would get there. But if he took the ♥♥♥? Then Leroy Jenkins would be alarmingly screwed.

Before he could come up with any reasonable ideas, Leroy Jenkins was interrupted by seven abrasive aligators that were lured by his ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. Leroy Jenkins sighed; 'Not again', he thought. Feeling frustrated, he thoughtfully reached for his mitten and aptly backhanded every last one of them. Apparently this was an adequate deterrent--the discouraged critters began to scurry back toward the thicket, squealing with discontent. He exhaled with relief. That's when he heard the ♥♥♥ rolling up. It was Civ 5.

----o0o----

As he pulled up, he felt a sense of urgency. He had had to make an unscheduled stop at Wal-Mart to pick up a 12-pack of pencils, so he knew he was running late. With a calculated leap, Civ 5 was out of the ♥♥♥ and went indiscriminately jaunting toward Leroy Jenkins's front door. Meanwhile inside, Leroy Jenkins was panicking. Not thinking, he tossed the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth into a box of mittens and then slid the box behind his piano. Leroy Jenkins was concerned but at least the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth was concealed. The doorbell rang.

'Come in,' Leroy Jenkins sassily purred. With a careful push, Civ 5 opened the door. 'Sorry for being late, but I was being chased by some funny-smelling maniac in a Vette,' he lied. 'It's fine,' Leroy Jenkins assured him. Civ 5 took a seat vaguely close to where Leroy Jenkins had hidden the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. Leroy Jenkins cringed trying unsuccessfully to hide his nervousness. 'Uhh, can I get you anything?' he blurted. But Civ 5 was distracted. Without warning, Leroy Jenkins noticed a selfish look on Civ 5's face. Civ 5 slowly opened his mouth to speak.

'...What's that smell?'

Leroy Jenkins felt a stabbing pain in his butt when Civ 5 asked this. In a moment of disbelief, he realized that he had hidden the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth right by his oscillating fan. 'Wh-what? I don't smell anything..!' A lie. A insensitive look started to form on Civ 5's face. He turned to notice a box that seemed clearly out of place. 'Th-th-those are just my grandma's mittens from when she used to have pet bunnies. She, uh...dropped 'em by here earlier'. Civ 5 nodded with fake acknowledgement...then, before Leroy Jenkins could react, Civ 5 randomly lunged toward the box and opened it. The ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth was plainly in view.

Civ 5 stared at Leroy Jenkins for what what must've been four seconds. Unexpectedly, Leroy Jenkins groped wildly in Civ 5's direction, clearly desperate. Civ 5 grabbed the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth and bolted for the door. It was locked. Leroy Jenkins let out a eccentric chuckle. 'If only you hadn't been so protective of that thing, none of this would have happened, Civ 5,' he rebuked. Leroy Jenkins always had been a little insensitive, so Civ 5 knew that reconciliation was not an option; he needed to escape before Leroy Jenkins did something crazy, like... start chucking mittens at him or something. All of a sudden, he gripped his ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth tightly and made a dash toward the window, diving headlong through the glass panels.

Leroy Jenkins looked on, blankly. 'What the hell? That seemed excessive. The other door was open, you know.' Silence from Civ 5. 'And to think, I varnished that window frame nine days ago...it never ends!' Suddenly he felt a tinge of concern for Civ 5. 'Oh. You ..okay?' Still silence. Leroy Jenkins walked over to the window and looked down. Civ 5 was gone.

----o0o----

Just yonder, Civ 5 was struggling to make his way through the pumpkin patch behind Leroy Jenkins's place. Civ 5 had severely hurt his arm during the window incident, and was starting to lose strength. Another pack of feral aligators suddenly appeared, having caught wind of the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. One by one they latched on to Civ 5. Already weakened from his injury, Civ 5 yielded to the furry onslaught and collapsed. The last thing he saw before losing consciousness was a buzzing horde of aligators running off with his ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth.

About seven hours later, Civ 5 awoke, his butt throbbing. It was dark and Civ 5 did not know where he was. Deep in the humid desert, Civ 5 was abundantly lost. A few minutes later, he remembered that his ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth was taken by the aligators. But at that point, he was just thankful for his life. That's when, to his horror, a oversized aligator emerged from the cornfield. It was the alpha aligator. Civ 5 opened his mouth to scream but was cut short when the aligator sunk its teeth into Civ 5's face. With a faint groan, the life escaped from Civ 5's lungs, but not before he realized that he was a failure.

Less than two miles away, Leroy Jenkins was entombed by anguish over the loss of the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. 'MY PRECIOUS!!' he cried, as he reached for a sharpened spoon. With a heroic thrust, he buried it deeply into his neck. As the room began to fade to black, he thought about Civ 5... wishing he had found the courage to tell him that he loved him. But he would die alone that day. All that remained was the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth that had turned them against each other, ultimately causing their demise. And as the dew on melancholy sappling branches began to reflect the dawn's reddish glare, all that could be heard was the chilling cry of distant aligators, desecrating all things sacred to virtuous men, and perpetuating an evil that would reign for centuries to come. Our heroes would've lived unhappily ever after, but they were too busy being dead. So, no one lived forever after, the end. :'(

reviewText:
8.5/10
(-1pt. bcause of the lagg that is encountered sometimes and -0.5pt. because people will still compare it with the first game of the series... including me <-call it just a personal preference)

Well, even tho the lagg in the multiplayer games can become an issue (multiplayer being a peer to peer thinghie), the game is pretty badass. Yeah, it's not the first DOW where u spammed units until your enemies would die. Yeah it's not Starcraft 2 (and for the love of the Emperor, stop comparing the two) where you need the dexterity of a piano player; but it's a game where tactics and strategy blend nicely. learn to abuse the retreat button in multiplayer. The learning curve is kinda steep, especially against veteran players BUT (and that's a big but) once you get the hang of it, you will realize that there aren't two games exactly the same. Let's take for ex the orks. Deadly at close range, with the right upgrades, will ♥♥♥♥ anything from afar too. A little word of advice for the new players tho: use space marines/force commander. The strategy is simple: run, conquer the requisition points, retreat, heal, harass, overcome and overpower. The MOD that people talk about it's not that important. The title is solid as it is. The only question that remains is... are you a loyalist or a traitorous scum?

reviewText:
Being a die hard DOWI fan, It took me a long while to warm up to the changes they made with DOWII, however now that they've stopped bombarding us with mini DLC's I decided to bite the bullet, get the entire game and give it a go.

Single player campaign.
Very action RPG very well done with a star map allowing you to pick your missions mostly, and a different campaign for each race.
Action RPG is not really my thing, but its still nice to play this on occasion.

Co-op campaign.
Not tried it, its nice that its here though.

Single player Skirmish.
This is more my style customize your game and experiment to find your favourite tactics and strategy.
DOWII has taken a very different approach to RTS than DOW I, essentially you have less units, no buildings, and more micro, all ideas I thought where bad, but they have produced good and distinctive tactic oriented game, the action feels alot mor intense here but if you can keep up it is very satisfying when you succeed. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

Multi-player Skirmish.
This is where things really heat up, and this is my favourite mode, be warned as with many game you will need to practice VS the AI before attempting to take on other players, but the huge arrange of units and sides and the beautifully done maps, animations etc all contribute to making this an unforgettable RTS experience. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

One of my favourite RTS games, recommended if you like both ACTION RPG or RTS or just W40K   - 8.5/10

One wish - that they included the Tau, fortunately there's a mod for that.

Civ 5 grabbed his desk and disembarked immediately. After hanging up the phone, Leroy Jenkins realized that he was in trouble. He had to find a place to hide the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth and he had to do it thoughtfully. He figured that if Civ 5 took the truck, he had take at least eleven minutes before Civ 5 would get there. But if he took the ♥♥♥? Then Leroy Jenkins would be alarmingly screwed.

Before he could come up with any reasonable ideas, Leroy Jenkins was interrupted by seven abrasive aligators that were lured by his ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. Leroy Jenkins sighed; 'Not again', he thought. Feeling frustrated, he thoughtfully reached for his mitten and aptly backhanded every last one of them. Apparently this was an adequate deterrent--the discouraged critters began to scurry back toward the thicket, squealing with discontent. He exhaled with relief. That's when he heard the ♥♥♥ rolling up. It was Civ 5.

----o0o----

As he pulled up, he felt a sense of urgency. He had had to make an unscheduled stop at Wal-Mart to pick up a 12-pack of pencils, so he knew he was running late. With a calculated leap, Civ 5 was out of the ♥♥♥ and went indiscriminately jaunting toward Leroy Jenkins's front door. Meanwhile inside, Leroy Jenkins was panicking. Not thinking, he tossed the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth into a box of mittens and then slid the box behind his piano. Leroy Jenkins was concerned but at least the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth was concealed. The doorbell rang.

'Come in,' Leroy Jenkins sassily purred. With a careful push, Civ 5 opened the door. 'Sorry for being late, but I was being chased by some funny-smelling maniac in a Vette,' he lied. 'It's fine,' Leroy Jenkins assured him. Civ 5 took a seat vaguely close to where Leroy Jenkins had hidden the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. Leroy Jenkins cringed trying unsuccessfully to hide his nervousness. 'Uhh, can I get you anything?' he blurted. But Civ 5 was distracted. Without warning, Leroy Jenkins noticed a selfish look on Civ 5's face. Civ 5 slowly opened his mouth to speak.

'...What's that smell?'

Leroy Jenkins felt a stabbing pain in his butt when Civ 5 asked this. In a moment of disbelief, he realized that he had hidden the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth right by his oscillating fan. 'Wh-what? I don't smell anything..!' A lie. A insensitive look started to form on Civ 5's face. He turned to notice a box that seemed clearly out of place. 'Th-th-those are just my grandma's mittens from when she used to have pet bunnies. She, uh...dropped 'em by here earlier'. Civ 5 nodded with fake acknowledgement...then, before Leroy Jenkins could react, Civ 5 randomly lunged toward the box and opened it. The ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth was plainly in view.

Civ 5 stared at Leroy Jenkins for what what must've been four seconds. Unexpectedly, Leroy Jenkins groped wildly in Civ 5's direction, clearly desperate. Civ 5 grabbed the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth and bolted for the door. It was locked. Leroy Jenkins let out a eccentric chuckle. 'If only you hadn't been so protective of that thing, none of this would have happened, Civ 5,' he rebuked. Leroy Jenkins always had been a little insensitive, so Civ 5 knew that reconciliation was not an option; he needed to escape before Leroy Jenkins did something crazy, like... start chucking mittens at him or something. All of a sudden, he gripped his ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth tightly and made a dash toward the window, diving headlong through the glass panels.

Leroy Jenkins looked on, blankly. 'What the hell? That seemed excessive. The other door was open, you know.' Silence from Civ 5. 'And to think, I varnished that window frame nine days ago...it never ends!' Suddenly he felt a tinge of concern for Civ 5. 'Oh. You ..okay?' Still silence. Leroy Jenkins walked over to the window and looked down. Civ 5 was gone.

----o0o----

Just yonder, Civ 5 was struggling to make his way through the pumpkin patch behind Leroy Jenkins's place. Civ 5 had severely hurt his arm during the window incident, and was starting to lose strength. Another pack of feral aligators suddenly appeared, having caught wind of the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. One by one they latched on to Civ 5. Already weakened from his injury, Civ 5 yielded to the furry onslaught and collapsed. The last thing he saw before losing consciousness was a buzzing horde of aligators running off with his ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth.

About seven hours later, Civ 5 awoke, his butt throbbing. It was dark and Civ 5 did not know where he was. Deep in the humid desert, Civ 5 was abundantly lost. A few minutes later, he remembered that his ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth was taken by the aligators. But at that point, he was just thankful for his life. That's when, to his horror, a oversized aligator emerged from the cornfield. It was the alpha aligator. Civ 5 opened his mouth to scream but was cut short when the aligator sunk its teeth into Civ 5's face. With a faint groan, the life escaped from Civ 5's lungs, but not before he realized that he was a failure.

Less than two miles away, Leroy Jenkins was entombed by anguish over the loss of the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. 'MY PRECIOUS!!' he cried, as he reached for a sharpened spoon. With a heroic thrust, he buried it deeply into his neck. As the room began to fade to black, he thought about Civ 5... wishing he had found the courage to tell him that he loved him. But he would die alone that day. All that remained was the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth that had turned them against each other, ultimately causing their demise. And as the dew on melancholy sappling branches began to reflect the dawn's reddish glare, all that could be heard was the chilling cry of distant aligators, desecrating all things sacred to virtuous men, and perpetuating an evil that would reign for centuries to come. Our heroes would've lived unhappily ever after, but they were too busy being dead. So, no one lived forever after, the end. :'(

reviewText:
8.5/10
(-1pt. bcause of the lagg that is encountered sometimes and -0.5pt. because people will still compare it with the first game of the series... including me <-call it just a personal preference)

Well, even tho the lagg in the multiplayer games can become an issue (multiplayer being a peer to peer thinghie), the game is pretty badass. Yeah, it's not the first DOW where u spammed units until your enemies would die. Yeah it's not Starcraft 2 (and for the love of the Emperor, stop comparing the two) where you need the dexterity of a piano player; but it's a game where tactics and strategy blend nicely. learn to abuse the retreat button in multiplayer. The learning curve is kinda steep, especially against veteran players BUT (and that's a big but) once you get the hang of it, you will realize that there aren't two games exactly the same. Let's take for ex the orks. Deadly at close range, with the right upgrades, will ♥♥♥♥ anything from afar too. A little word of advice for the new players tho: use space marines/force commander. The strategy is simple: run, conquer the requisition points, retreat, heal, harass, overcome and overpower. The MOD that people talk about it's not that important. The title is solid as it is. The only question that remains is... are you a loyalist or a traitorous scum?

reviewText:
Being a die hard DOWI fan, It took me a long while to warm up to the changes they made with DOWII, however now that they've stopped bombarding us with mini DLC's I decided to bite the bullet, get the entire game and give it a go.

Single player campaign.
Very action RPG very well done with a star map allowing you to pick your missions mostly, and a different campaign for each race.
Action RPG is not really my thing, but its still nice to play this on occasion.

Co-op campaign.
Not tried it, its nice that its here though.

Single player Skirmish.
This is more my style customize your game and experiment to find your favourite tactics and strategy.
DOWII has taken a very different approach to RTS than DOW I, essentially you have less units, no buildings, and more micro, all ideas I thought where bad, but they have produced good and distinctive tactic oriented game, the action feels alot mor intense here but if you can keep up it is very satisfying when you succeed. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

Multi-player Skirmish.
This is where things really heat up, and this is my favourite mode, be warned as with many game you will need to practice VS the AI before attempting to take on other players, but the huge arrange of units and sides and the beautifully done maps, animations etc all contribute to making this an unforgettable RTS experience. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

One of my favourite RTS games, recommended if you like both ACTION RPG or RTS or just W40K   - 8.5/10

One wish - that they included the Tau, fortunately there's a mod for that.

reviewText: This is a great RTS, and the campaign is full of story and action. Great character designs, and I loved the number of available races. Dawn of War II is a must-have for any RTS group player, Warhammer fan, science fiction fan, or just somebody looking to have a good time, for a long time. You will NOT get bored for quite a long time, it is a very fulfilling game with more than enough to entertain you for months.

reviewText:
Dawn of War II is a huge step backwards from the original Dawn of War series (winter assault, dark crusade, soulstorm). Why they ever decided to throw base building and big-scale wars out of the window in a strategy game is beyond me. Command and conquer 4 made the same massive mistake as all of the Dawn fo War II series did.

No more big battles, no more base building, no more really epic units battling it out, no more epic long games. Just you and a handful of squads versus an enemy with a handful of squads in games that usually don't last very long. There's not much room for strategizing and diversification with such a small pool of things to do stuff with. The entire game feels more like you're participating in a few small-scale guerilla warfare missions rather than a real epic war.

Graphics and sounds aside, which are actually pretty decent and a reasonable improvement over the original series, I really cannot recommend this to anyone who's a fan of the original series. If you are new to Dawn of war in its entirety, then sure, you can give this a shot. It can be an ok time sink. But in my opinion, you'd still be better off just going with the original Dawn of War anyway, rather than this one. Only the campaign is reasonably fun to play due to the storyline. but even then many of the things in the campaign (including the missions themselves) constantly repeat no matter which race you play it through with next, so it doesn't give you any reason to play it again after you played it out once.

TL;DR - Overall, I just don't recommend it at all, nor do I recommend any of the other Dawn of War II games. I would much rather point people to Dawn of War: Dark Crusade or Soulstorm. Even when Dawn of War II isn't compared to anything, it still only reaches a 5/10 rating in my opinion, at the very best. An 'ok' time sink, but not much else.

Trying to be innovative and new is all well and good, but that does not warrant completely annihilating a working (and fun) formula, which the original series was most popular for.

reviewText:
Stellar, absolutly fantastic. i love everything about the game!

core gameplay - a straight continuation of the great Dawn of War 2 - RTS with focuses solely on unit tactics and no base building.
you will have to take care of every single unit you have, position it the right way, make sure it covers the right area, and its in proper cover. use every one of your units' special abilities to turn the tide of combat. and make use of global abilities to decimate your foes.

the lack of base building only enhances the experience - less focus on your off-battle base and more micro and tactics in the actual battle.

what adds more to the experience is how different this game's singleplayer than the original DoW2 - instead of just starting with 4 squads and nothing more. you start only with 4 heroes and can buy additional squads and units as you progress through the level.
this  makes long-term descions with what units to buy at what time and what weapon to equip them with - all the more exciting.
and despite the fact that i liked the original's campegin more. this is still a fresh and exiciting way to take on the SP.

now a very important note: the presentation are BLOODY AMAZING,
the graphics are beutiful and every unit is very detailed. the effects of explosions, plasma shots and blood are awsome the physics of how rocks and buildngs fall apart as the battle rages on is facinating.

and to top it all off, great voice acting. every unit has great responses and LOTS of them. they even respond differetly to every kind of enemy they face. the amount of detail in this game is simply unmatched.

this is a must-have for every RTS fan. who cares about the base building if the combat is what really matters? if basebuilding is what you want. go play a city building game or stronghold.

reviewText:
A good game, but lack of optimization means that people with older PCs can't play it very well. Even higher end PCs do have a little bit of trouble with the graphical load, but that's few and far between.

The player community, on the other hand, is often toxic to an extreme. Multiplayer is good, but matchmaking is not. The complaints that people have for DOTA 2, especially against Russian players, is very much extant here, especially with regards to teamwork, as well as loadtimes (because for some reason, most Russian players cannot afford decent computers or set their settings to low, and often use vulgar language when asked to cooperate with host requests or to work with teammates.

The learning curve is steep, and I have to say I took several hundred hours in Vanilla DOW2 and Chaos Rising to get to some degree of skill, enough to reliably defeat opponents. To be very frank, this is not a newbie friendly game. The micromanagement required to perform well, or at least at any decent standard of play, is quite above the average micromanagement capacity of a newbie.

As for ELITE mod, though I have personal misgivings against a mod created by someone who felt that DOW2 wasn't balanced and as such balanced it to suit his own tastes (Which to be honest is enterprising, but reeking utterly of hypocrisy), it is a fun mod to play, even though the community is even tinier than the already small DOW2 community.

The campaign, well, is fun at first, but loses its novelty when one compares it to the original DOW2 and Chaos Rising, which have a dedicated and properly fleshed out campaign with multiple choices. The fact that THQ actually reused campaign maps and storylines for each faction is indicative of their slide into mediocrity and bankruptcy - no game designer should be that lazy.

Overall, this is a fun game to play. I have put many hours into it, and likely will continue to for the foreseeable future.

reviewText: The most recent Warhammer 40k stratigy game. Will continue to allow online play after the other DoW2 interations die due to the ending of Games for Windows Live. Focuses heavily on squad combat, with resource aqusition reduced to territory control; the only way to get what you need is to hold ground. Results in a far more enjoyable tactical experience than games like Star Craft 2, where holding ground and tactical expasion is much less important relatively. Factions are not all perfectly balanced, but there's a good number to choose from (not as many as in the final DoW 1 expansion, but I'm not sure if you can still play DoW 1 online).\nGameplay: http://youtu.be/YZspVqpbM4k

reviewText: I find it difficult to enjoy Retribution, but I will recommend it with certain reservations. One the one hand, the small unit tactics and powerful feel of 2 and Chaos Rising has been preserved. On the other, there's no actual difference between campaigns. If I use Imperial Guard, for example, the campaign is utterly identical to the Tyranid or Eldar campaigns with the obvious exception of who I'm actually playing as. Most of the campaign missions are exercises in flooding the map with as many troops as possible in the vain hope of killing the massive monster with more health than a tank before it squishes everyone on the field. One late game mission comes to mind wherein a massive biological nightmare is attacking an unarmed APC that conveniently has your only way out on board. This thing has more health than most armored vehicles and can near instantly kill most infantry sent at it, and due to the mission itself, infantry is all you can send at it. One early mission has the player party of cardboard boxes intercepting and destroying a light armored convoy with no anti armor weapons avaliable due to how early in the game it is. Eventually the only solution is to barricade the exits with gun turrets and hope massed infantry fire will kill the vehicles. The best mission by far is roughly middle of the game, during which the player and party revisit a location from Chaos Rising and finally put an end to the big baddy from that game. This mission was certainly frustrating for a number of reasons, but it added a certain sense of closure to the whole plot line that wasn't present in Chaos Rising. IN short, this game is rather flawed but certainly playable if grinding is acceptable.

reviewText: Dawn of War II Retribution. As I'm WH40K freak I had a big expectations to that game, especially after a very good Dawn of War II and interesting Chaos Rising. The campaign made me a lot interested as they wanted to let us play all 5+1 races (All that was in DoW II and CR + the one they added in Retribution) but all I can say, the game went through my expectations. It is a very decent RTS games, with a great story in Warhammer 40K lore, which fits it's nicely. The gameplay is a mix between first Dawn of War(Which was great as well) and the new mechanics from DoW II. The arts and graphic of the game reflects the Warhammer 40K world as a real, bloody world where there is no peace. Last stand mode adds as well very much to the game to keep it more interesting and the multiplayer is done really good.\n\nMy score for this game is 10+/10.

reviewText: I find it difficult to enjoy Retribution, but I will recommend it with certain reservations. One the one hand, the small unit tactics and powerful feel of 2 and Chaos Rising has been preserved. On the other, there's no actual difference between campaigns. If I use Imperial Guard, for example, the campaign is utterly identical to the Tyranid or Eldar campaigns with the obvious exception of who I'm actually playing as. Most of the campaign missions are exercises in flooding the map with as many troops as possible in the vain hope of killing the massive monster with more health than a tank before it squishes everyone on the field. One late game mission comes to mind wherein a massive biological nightmare is attacking an unarmed APC that conveniently has your only way out on board. This thing has more health than most armored vehicles and can near instantly kill most infantry sent at it, and due to the mission itself, infantry is all you can send at it. One early mission has the player party of cardboard boxes intercepting and destroying a light armored convoy with no anti armor weapons avaliable due to how early in the game it is. Eventually the only solution is to barricade the exits with gun turrets and hope massed infantry fire will kill the vehicles. The best mission by far is roughly middle of the game, during which the player and party revisit a location from Chaos Rising and finally put an end to the big baddy from that game. This mission was certainly frustrating for a number of reasons, but it added a certain sense of closure to the whole plot line that wasn't present in Chaos Rising. IN short, this game is rather flawed but certainly playable if grinding is acceptable.

reviewText:
The epic Dawn of War series is back and is better than ever with this stand-alone expansion to Dawn of War 2.

There are game modes for everyone, with a player able to play campaign solo or with co-op,     a objectives-based multiplayer mode and a 3-player co-op mode, The Last Stand, where players work together to fight their way to the elusive Wave 20.

A must-buy for any fans of the Dawn of War franchise.

reviewText: Dawn of War II Retribution. As I'm WH40K freak I had a big expectations to that game, especially after a very good Dawn of War II and interesting Chaos Rising. The campaign made me a lot interested as they wanted to let us play all 5+1 races (All that was in DoW II and CR + the one they added in Retribution) but all I can say, the game went through my expectations. It is a very decent RTS games, with a great story in Warhammer 40K lore, which fits it's nicely. The gameplay is a mix between first Dawn of War(Which was great as well) and the new mechanics from DoW II. The arts and graphic of the game reflects the Warhammer 40K world as a real, bloody world where there is no peace. Last stand mode adds as well very much to the game to keep it more interesting and the multiplayer is done really good.\n\nMy score for this game is 10+/10.

reviewText:
This is worth picking up for the Last Stand alone.

The campaigns (which are all EXACTLY THE SAME, just with different characters) are just a kind of bonus of sorts. They're not great, but I enjoyed some of them. Just play the Orks campaign, theirs is the best one. Maybe Tyranids too.

Just, if you DO get this game? I recommend you grab the Wargear DLC. Not the stupid skins, you don't want or need most of those. Just get the DLC that gives you bonus stuff for Last Stand. Everything in the DLC is not overpowered, no, but most of it will help you. A lot. It's all useful.

Except the Mek Boy stuff. Teleboom op.

Got friends? You'll have hours of fun! Got no friends? Ah well, you'll find 2 other people through the matchmaker easily enough. Trust me, you can find people at any time.

Pick it up some time.

reviewText:
Ok, well first of all, I come from playing Dawn of war 1 and its expansions, I skipped DOW2 and Chaos Rising. That being said, this game is very different.

For multiplayer I would say this game is excellent, if you can get good enough to beat the skilled people who play. Quite a learning curve unless you're really good at RTS's .Also, the Last Stand Mode was amazing.

In my opinion the Campaign was quite weak, but I suppose that can be excused by trying to create a storyline for 6 races. However, Dawn of War 1 dark crusade did this with 7 races and made an amazing game, with a decent story.

One of my major complaints about this game is that it takes FOREVER to kill a unit, and more often than not, they just rout (run away super fast so you can't catch them) and regroup. I realize that does add some strategy to the game, but overall the battles are just not as fun or as dramatic as in DOW 1.

So here's the summary:

Gameplay:

Singleplayer: 4/10
Multiplayer: 8/10

Graphics and Sounds are both about 7/10. I know people will say that i'm wrong with this, but I really liked the cartoony-but-cool graphics from DOW1 and the sound as well. This is, after all, my opinion.

Anyhoo, that's what I think, thx for reading.

reviewText:
I believe that Dawn of War 2 is a shining paragon of the RTS genre.
The combat mechanics are intuitive, very skill-based, and hard to master, while also being easy to pick up and learn for beginners.
Retribution manages to find a nice sweet-spot between micro and macro-based RTS, something that few games in the genre manage to achieve, so it can please players of both to an extent.
The game's replayability is very high, coming with a whopping (by today's standards) 6 fully playable races, campaigns for each (all with a very well done RPG-style item and upgrade system), a polished multiplayer with several game modes and lots of maps (holy ♥♥♥♥, it actually takes STRATEGY and THINKING to be good at!). There's also the The Last Stand" gametype
date: a 3-player co-op defensive arena where you fight off various waves of enemies with your chosen heroes.\nInsipid lag compensation system aside
recommended: the multiplayer is fairly smooth.\nAnd yes
hoursPlayed: the original was better

reviewText:
Ok, I normally can't be bothered to write a review, but there's a few things you should know before paying anything other than 75% off for this game. I'll keep it simple.

Single player campaign feels like a rushed afterthought. No more cool planetary backdrops or watching your ship jump into a new system. Now you get a static map and dumbed down levelling system. DoW II is better if you want single player, unless you simply HAVE to play as Orks/Eldar etc.

But wait! Multiplayer is what it's all about anyway right? It could be, but seeing as finding a public game that doesn't boot you out after the countdown reaches zero is next to impossible, you're limited to private matches.

The Last Stand works fine, but if you only want to play that you can buy it seperately anyway.

Overall it's a shame, as DoW II is good fun, especially in multiplayer, but without the ability to actually play public matches, all Retribution really brings to the table is a new race to play as. On your own. If you want a solid multiplayer strategy game with an active community and servers that (mostly) work, get CoH instead.

reviewText:
This is not a good game.

I love the last stand gamemode and the fact that Tyranids are now a thing, but that's where my love for this game ends.
I'll start right off with the absolute worst thing about this game: Tau are DLC and, soon enough, you'll have to pay for the Necron DLC as well, although for the time being it is free.
What the ♥♥♥♥!?
I can play those two in DARK CRUSADE if I want to! You shouldn't have to pay extra for content that was IN PREVIOUS GAMES!
The Tau and Necrons were my favourite factions, and now I have to pay *extra money* to play as them because the publishers are such bloody ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.

And what's more, they completely ruined skirmish mode! The gameplay is entirely different and it's the kind of thing I'd expect from something that ISN'T part of the DoW series. It completely deviates from all the games before it, and it sucks.
They also got rid of that sandbox-y campaign and it's now linear.

Long story short: If you want to play Dawn of War, play Dark Crusade or Soulstorm. Not this pathetic excuse for a Dawn of War title.

reviewText:
Orks, Eldars and Tyranids, oh my!

DoW2:Retribution is the third installment of the Dawn of War 2 saga and a succesfull one at that.
The campaign, one for each race, got a respectable playtime and also extremely fun to play with a friend!
However DoW2 is an RTS at heart, and thus have MP as focus.

DoW2 sticks out alot compared to fellow RTS game of making a base and mass produce units. Here you only have one building that will do all of it for you. And for every loving warhammer nerd out there, this game is a must have! Unless you don't like RTS games.

Things like using the terrain for cover, or using a force push to send your own or the enemies troops to a location all makes DOW2 a unique RTS game that focus much more on you to take care of every squad you have. Retreat when necessary, roll in a tank to smash through walls when also necessary!

With 6 Races, the game comes fairly balanced for an RTS. Should be considered purchase for the MP possibilities. 4/5
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong, I have tons of hours on this game, but it doesn't mean I stand proud next to it. 55 hours spread through the years now and mainly because for some time i didn't have any other games and i had  no internet connection so I only played skirmishes against AI.
I bought the game without knowing what it was, i just hopped in and hoped it was good... Which is not a bad game, but I was hoping, when i bought a couple years ago as a disk (which i still have..) that there was going to be base building in this game. There's none and for me it was such a let down. I mean i know a bit about the 40k universe, you don't paint buildings, you paint armies which i absolutly respect not adding any of that stuff but to me, RTS rhymed with bas building and i was disappointed to be honest.

Now i reinstalled the game because devoleppers gave a new playable character for free, the Necron Overlord, for the game mode called The last Stand, so i gave it a try. First of all, i was happy to get something new, and free, after all these years i bought the game, it was a nice surprise out of nowhere. So i tried the guy, didn't really liked it, but i stayed for the game mode... And now i play almost everyday the damn thing.

As i read in the reviews, came for the Dawn Of War, stayed for the Last Stand. But it's not worth the price tag. I know a lot of of effort is behind this game, lots and lots of detail, beautiful visuals that still looks amazing after the years but the Campaign is boring, and repetitive (all the races have almost the same story, if not the same) Customization is still limited in my opinion (from the point of view of the hobbyist who paints his figurines, this game is not giving the same freedom , at all, but still holds proudly the title of Warhammer ..), Multiplayer is so ♥♥♥♥ing hard, the matchmaking is a pain, I'm not playing to be the best, I'm playing to have a good time but i just can't in this game. So all i'm left with is a nice little game mode, which i wish i could've bought, if it was possible, seperatly.

So yeh, not my favorite, but still partially fun to play. I thought about writting about it for a long time, so here it is.

reviewText:
Seemed like a good idea for $13.75 with all the DLC. However, it seemed that Relic Entertainment didn't provide any updates to resolve the slow load times or co-op multiplayer issues. It could be due to the free weekend overload but I doubt it.

PROS
1. Theme
Interesting story about the Blood Ravens, Exterminatus and how all the different factions play a role in the overarching story. I like how they made sure all the races melded into one main story.

2. Wargear & Skills
I like the customisation of skills and equipment. The 3 different skill trees (Combat, Health and Energy) add a small change in playstyle.

3. Multi-Race Campaign
Nice to know that each race has its own campaign.

4. Last Stand
Fun. Gets a little boring playing the same match though.

CONS
1. Load Times
For some reason, the game requires one to wait for 2 whole minutes before one can start a map and another 2 whole minutes before one can close the game. This is a major downer for me. For a 2011 game, it is quite odd.

2. Server Issues
While trying to play Last Stand, the game hangs after the countdown finishes. It is only during some rare occasion that a game starts up.

3. Repetitive
Control your leader and his honour guard, attack or defend, break open crates, capture points and bases. Every single location seems to be exactly the same. The only major difference tends to be a boss fight, other than that there is nothing unique.

4. Overly-Simplified Campaign
The way you capture the bases at fixed locations is quite odd. It's as if a base was magically planned to be there. Sometimes, the bases are redundant as your hero can just summon units. E.g. Hive Lord calling in Genestealers

5. Cover
Unsure if it's even necessary. While it is possible to hide behind cover, there isn't a real need to.

6. AI
The AI is just silly, it can't path around simple blockages or auto-attack enemies. E.g. Genestealers don't know how to go around an obstacle to attack. You have to break the obstacle with your Hive Lord before the Genestealers know how to attack.

7. Unit Supply
I really do not understand why you have to capture a supply building. I can understand capturing Requisition and Power but the whole idea of a satellite dish providing supply seems odd. The theme just doesn't sync with the idea of unit supply.

8. Redundant Heavy Units
You don't really have to destroy bases in the campaign, so it makes you wonder why you need vehicles/heavies at all. You hardly see turrets in except in the early stages of the campaign and even then you can deal with the turrets without heavies.

9. Resource Crates
You have to manually Right Click on the Requisition and Power that appear after a crate is broken. It's quite tedious and does not provide any fun. Why couldn't they just automatically collect the resources when they fall out? The same problem applies to dropped Accessories and Hero Equipment.

10. Abilities
Lots of visual effects but no impact.
a. The casting is not smooth. There is a long windup before certain abilities trigger, which may result in misses. E.g. Hive Lord's Plasma Barrage
b. Inaccurate E.g. Doombolt from the Chaos Sorceror

The best executed abilities seem to be those that do not require aiming and are centred on the hero. E.g. AOE heal or Doomblast.

11. Last Stand Lack of Diversity
Why can't we use all the commanders? Why is it restricted to 1 from each race?

NEUTRAL
1. Unit Design
I'm a bit aghast at how some units were designed. This is a personal preference but I thought I ought to write it out. E.g. Tyranid ranged units (Termagaunts, Hive Lord) and their hose gun" concept.

SUGGESTIONS
1. Ping Column for Multiplayer
I can't see the ping to another player. I would prefer a lag-free game instead of a 200-400ms lag game."

reviewText:
I came back to DOW2: Retribution after a long hiatus and I can honestly say: I would NOT recommend this game to anyone.  It is a poor and feels like a rush and sloppy continuation of the series.

Pros:
1. You can play 6 of the Warhammer 40K races in campaign and multiplayer
2. Co Op campaign with a friend
3. custom color your army for multiplayer
4. new DLC skins for troops and Last Stand
5. The Last Stand is fun

Cons:
1. The multiplayer takes far to long to find a ranked game.  Likewise, there are very few NonRanked games avaialble at times.
2. The races are always unbalanced, despite the amount of updates released.
3. The units LEVEL UP makes it impossible to fight back or even start a counter attack near the game's end.  This only makes the opposing side quit early or just lose interst in playing any further.
4. Campaign is linear and has the same story arch, with no variation for either race.  Every Map has no freedom of movement, which forces players to go in ONE direction.  This was never a factor in the previous DOW II installments.
5. People who bought hte Collector's Edition were cheated out of their money for rubbish cards and a small poster.  For the same price I expect an art book, a soundtrack or more.  I purchased the C.E. upon pre-order and I was utterly disgusted by what was offered.  Their advertisement for the items was very misleading.
6. Units are expensive, you spend more time managing them than playing the game.

Too add: I have been giving this game so many benefits of a doubt that I just finally said, it fails". A Game is ment to be fun and exciting
date: DOWII: Retribution kills that by making you feel RUSHED
hoursPlayed: & ANGRY.\nIt takes a lot to get me mad
voteText: and this game has pushed that button. Other RTS games were challanging but at least they were fun and had preferable replay value.\n\nDOW: Retribution is so unbalanced it's annoying. Every race is expensive

reviewText:
I DONT RECOMMEND THIS GAME FOR DAWN OF WAR 1 FANS. this game is decent as a separate game, but it claims to be  from the dawn of war name but it PLAYS NOTHING LIKE DOW1!.ill number down the reasons.IT SHOULD HAVE BEEN ANOTHER GAME entirely.

1-lack of variety the units types are significally numbered down for example Space marines(expansion included) had about 17 units, now is numbed again down whit only 8 or so. also DOW used to have 9 races(whit expansions)  DOW2 whit expansion has the grand total of only 6......

2-There is no builder unit and beacuse of that there are no building to be build, you just buy them from your HQ which numbs the game down into just a tactical stratey game inteads of a hydrid RTS that was DoW1. you cant longet build turrets, barrack etc or  keep unlocking technologys like a RTS should be and DoW was.

3-The special kills that used to be so prevalent in DoW1 are almost missing in DoW2.

4- Squad size and equipment selection is also numbed down. what was a Space marine whit a squad size of 10, is now fully upgraded in DoW 2 only size 4. in DoW1 you could have different weapons add ons in the same squad, for example a Space marine squad whit two plasmas and 2 bazookas, this is no longer true in DoW2 you ca only equip one add on and equip it to only 1 squad member.

5- DoW1 where you captured resource points and build energy at your base,. in DOW2 you capture bot on the field (resources and energy) and cant no longer build a turret to defend the command points.

6- No longer have multiple heroes instead you choose from only 3 available ones at start. that will determine how you play... or so they claim they basically fight in a bunch of units.

Those are the major diferences whit all of this changes DOW2 feels like a capture the flag game just taking a point to be taken back later and retaken by you again, there little about strategy here basically go whit your entire units in one big bunch and take point after point and battle agains another big bunch of units doings the same. there basically no strategy here.

They tried to mix the excelent system of Company of heroes whit some DoW dashed in there. if only they did it right in COH you  took command of points 3 to be expecific (gas,ammo and  the star thingy) but they needed to be linked up whit the base in order to receive you resources. you could have a unit take a strategic point between the connecting points and cut off their resources from them enteriley by breaking the chain, by doing that they manage to have a fast but STRATEGIC game and here is not the case in DOW2 it feels like and asymetrical DOTA.

reviewText:
I hate this game, plain and simple. The first game was awsome and had all the features I want in a RTS, while this is just a ♥♥♥♥ MOBA game. Despite the fact I adore the Warhammer franchise despite all the crappy retcons and bad management descions I just can't play this pile of crap. When they take down the servers in a few years it won't even work becasue there is no skirmish mode. You have to play an online match against bots that you can't kill because everytime you hit one of their units it runs away and heals up.

Also tanks are OP. If you expect the Great Unclean one to be worth your time, don't. The only other daemon units die before they can even engage the enemy most of the time becasue they lose health at a ridiculous rate outside of combat.

No base building either. This game pulled a Skyrim and made the franchise something prettier to look at, but under its skin its simpler in a bad, annyoing way that isn't fun for some people.

Lot's of people like it, but I hate this game.

all and all, if you buy this game you wont be makeing a mistake, just not the best choice out there, for a better experiance I'd advise Company of Heros. Vegan pancakes recipe:

-1 Cup of wheat flour
-1 Tablespoon of potato flour
-1 Cup of Soya milk
-1 Teaspoon of Apple vinegar
-1 teaspoon of baking powder
-1 pinch of salt
-1 teaspoon of sugar
-1 tablespoon of oil + oil for frying
-Cocoa, synthetic honey

>Sift flour, salt and baking powder to some dish for the dough.
>Add milk, vinegar and sugar.
>Mix everything. It needs to be a little more dense than pancakes.
>While mixing, add oil.
>Fry on low amount of oil, both sides.
>After frying, drop some coccoa on it.

It seems that since the last game they've taken a huge leap backwards.

reviewText: So I just bought the Dawn of War II Retribution for mainly nostalgic reasons since I used to play alot of the first Dawn of War and loved it. Once I installed the game I played a bit of the Campaign then vs'd bots in a custom game and it hits me. THIS GAME BLOWS! They removed all base building ♥♥♥♥ the UI is confusing asf and the AI are so unrelenting and random its like playing a goose chase. *Captures a Requisition point*, *Base gets attacked*, *Go back to base, defend*, *Ooh the requisition point is under attack*... This is essentially the essence of the game, they have made it so hard to think strategically since from the moment you start the game the AI are doing random ♥♥♥♥ like sending units to attack your HQ and just being a pest.. This ruined my day and will ruin yours if you buy.

던 오브 워 시리즈의 최신작이 벌써 나온지 4년이 됩니다.
워해머의 팬에게... 준수한 워해머 전략시뮬레이션은 가뭄의 단비 같은 것일텐데요.

이 게임의 문제점을 따지자면 끝이 없지만, 가장 큰 문제점은 동시접속자가 400명도 되지 않는다는 점과 사후처리가 전혀 되지 않는다는 점이 있겠네요. 벌써 보고된지 4년째 되는 버그가 아직도 고쳐지지 않고 있으며, 앞으로도 고쳐지지 않을 것입니다. 동시 접속자 400명 중 당신을 제외한 399명은 전원 10년간 워해머만 플레이 해온 사람들이구요.
게임에 접속하는 순간, 당신의 유닛들은 기지에서 벗어나지도 못한채 포격을 받고 수류탄을 맞고 기지 방어 터렛들이 불타오르고 HQ가 폭발할겁니다.

사지마세요.
그냥... 차라리 제가 아미 빌려드릴테니 미니어쳐 게임을 하세요.

reviewText: Was really hyped to hear about every faction having their own campaign until I started another playthrough with a friend and it turns out each race is just C&P'd into this mostly-boring campaign. There are a few really good missions but most are tedious and/or too easy. Uneven difficulty and a short campaign makes it hard to justify playing on higher difficulties. Besides that, you basically have Chaos Rising's MP modes and units. Unless you are a big IG fan I would recommend getting the original and/or Chaos Rising (which I loved but I'm a huge Chaos fan) instead.
